2406 Shares of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">UAL </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">parent </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">United Airlines </ENAMEX>, were extremely active <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">all day Friday </TIMEX>, reacting to news and rumors about the proposed <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 6 . 79 billion </NUMEX>buy - out of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">airline </ENAMEX>by an employee - management <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">group </ENAMEX>.

2970 Several <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>could be seen shaking their heads when the news flashed .

3499 For example , their selling caused trading halts to be declared in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">USAir Group </ENAMEX>, which closed down <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">3 7 \/ 8 </NUMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">41 1 \/ 2 </NUMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Delta Air Lines </ENAMEX>, which fell <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">7 3 \/ 4 </NUMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">69 1 \/ 4 </NUMEX>, and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Philips Industries </ENAMEX>, which sank <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">3 </NUMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">21 1 \/ 2 </NUMEX>.

4010 Selling snowballed because of waves of automatic ` stop - loss ' orders , which are triggered by computer when prices fall to certain levels . 
4147 Most of the stock selling pressure came from Wall Street <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">professionals </ENAMEX>, including computer - guided program <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>. 
4262 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Traders </ENAMEX>said most of their major institutional <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">investors </ENAMEX>, on the other hand , sat tight . 
4352 Now , at <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">3 : 07 </TIMEX>, <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of the market ' s post - crash ` reforms ' took hold as the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX><NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">500 </NUMEX>futures contract had plunged <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">12 </NUMEX>points , equivalent to around a <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">100 </NUMEX>- point drop in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Dow </ENAMEX>industrials . 
4534 Under an agreement signed by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Chicago Mercantile Exchange </ENAMEX>, trading was temporarily halted in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Chicago </ENAMEX>. 
4659 After the trading halt in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX><NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">500 </NUMEX>pit in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Chicago </ENAMEX>, waves of selling continued to hit stocks themselves on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>, and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">specialists </ENAMEX>continued to notch prices down . 
4831 As a result , the link between the futures and stock markets ripped apart . 
4905 Without the guidepost of stock - index futures - - the barometer of where <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>think the overall stock market is headed - - many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>were afraid to trust stock prices quoted on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>. 
5100 The futures halt was even assailed by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>floor <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>. 
5163 ` It screwed things up , ' said <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>major <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">specialist </ENAMEX>. 
5216 This confusion effectively halted <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>form of program trading , stock index arbitrage , that closely links the futures and stock markets , and has been blamed by some for the market ' s big swings . 
5409 -LRB- In a stock - index arbitrage sell program , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>buy or sell big baskets of stocks and offset the trade in futures to lock in a price difference . -RRB- 
5559 ` When the airline information came through , it cracked every model we had for the marketplace , ' said a managing <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">director </ENAMEX>at <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of the largest program - trading <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>. 
5725 ` We did n't even get a chance to do the programs we wanted to do . ' 
5793 But stocks kept falling . 
5818 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Dow </ENAMEX>industrials were down <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">55 </NUMEX>points at <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">3 p . m . </TIMEX>before the futures - trading halt .

'

7894 At <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Merrill Lynch &amp; Co . </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">nation </ENAMEX>' s biggest brokerage <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>, a news release was prepared headlined ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">Merrill Lynch Comments on Market Drop </ENAMEX>. ' 
8034 The release cautioned that ` there are significant differences between the current environment and that of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October 1987 </TIMEX>' and that there are still ` attractive investment opportunities ' in the stock market . 
8240 However , <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Jeffrey B . Lane </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc . </ENAMEX>, said that <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s plunge is ` going to set back ' relations with <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">customers </ENAMEX>, ` because it reinforces the concern of volatility . 
8433 And I think a lot of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>will harp on program trading . 
8491 It ' s going to bring the debate right back to the forefront . ' 
8554 As the Dow average ground to its final <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">190 . 58 </NUMEX>loss <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX>pit stayed locked at its <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">30 </NUMEX>- point trading limit . 
8670 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Jeffrey Yass </ENAMEX>of program trader <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Susquehanna Investment Group </ENAMEX>said <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">2 , 000 </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX>contracts were for sale on the close , the equivalent of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 330 million </NUMEX>in stock . 
8824 But there were no <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">buyers </ENAMEX>. 
8852 While <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s debacle involved mainly professional <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>rather than <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>, it left the market vulnerable to continued selling <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">this morning </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>said . 
9014 Stock - index futures contracts settled at much lower prices than indexes of the stock market itself . 
9114 At those levels , stocks are set up to be hammered by index <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">arbitragers </ENAMEX>, who lock in profits by buying futures when futures prices fall , and simultaneously sell off stocks . 
9286 But nobody knows at what level the futures and stocks will open <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>. 
9359 The de - linkage between the stock and futures markets <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>will undoubtedly cause renewed debate about whether Wall Street is properly prepared for another crash situation . 
9533 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>' s Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Grasso </ENAMEX>said , ` Our systemic performance was good . ' 
9603 But the exchange will ` look at the performance of all <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">specialists </ENAMEX>in all stocks .

9811 -LRB- See related story : ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">Fed Ready to Inject Big Funds </ENAMEX>' - - <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">WSJ </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Oct . 16 , 1989 </TIMEX>-RRB-

9 When the news broke of an attempted coup in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Panama </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">two weeks ago </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Christopher Dodd </ENAMEX>called the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">State Department </ENAMEX>for a briefing .

189 That shows how far <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Ted Turner </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Cable News Network </ENAMEX>has come since its birth <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">nine years ago </TIMEX>, when it was considered the laughingstock of television news . 
342 It is bigger , faster and more profitable than the news <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">divisions </ENAMEX>of any of the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">three </NUMEX>major broadcast <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">networks </ENAMEX>.

600 Although viewership soars when big news breaks , it ebbs during periods of calm .

1032 ` You ca n't live on that . ' 
1060 So <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CNN </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">unit </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Atlanta </ENAMEX>- based <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Turner Broadcasting System Inc . </ENAMEX>, is trying to reposition itself as a primary <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">channel </ENAMEX>, or what <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>in the television industry call a ` top of mind ' <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">network </ENAMEX>.

2747 The repositioning bid is aimed at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CNN </ENAMEX>' s unsteady viewership - - and what may happen to it as the cable - TV news market grows more competitive . 
2888 Already , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CNN </ENAMEX>is facing stronger competition from <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Financial News Network Inc . </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">General Electric Co . </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Consumer News </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Business Channel </ENAMEX>, both of which are likely to pursue more general news in the future .

9 Predicting the financial results of computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>has been a tough job lately . 
91 Take <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft Corp . </ENAMEX>, the largest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">maker </ENAMEX>of personal computer software and generally considered an industry bellwether . 
210 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>stunned Wall Street with the prediction that growth in the personal computer business overall would be <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">only 10 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1990 </TIMEX>, a modest increase when compared with the sizzling expansion of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">years past </TIMEX>. 
429 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Investors </ENAMEX>- - taking this as a sign that a broad industry slump was in the offing - - reacted by selling the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s stock , which lost <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 3 . 25 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">that day </TIMEX>to close at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 52 </NUMEX>in national over - the - counter trading . 
635 But that was <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">all of three months ago </TIMEX>. 
675 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Last week </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft </ENAMEX>said it expects revenue for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its first quarter ended Sept . 30 </TIMEX>to increase <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">34 % </NUMEX>.

863 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft </ENAMEX>' s surprising strength is <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>example of the difficulty facing <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>looking for reassurances about the financial health of the computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>.

2257 While the earnings picture confuses , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">observers </ENAMEX>say the major forces expected to shape the industry in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the coming year </TIMEX>are clearer . 
2390 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Companies </ENAMEX>will continue to war over standards . 
2437 In computer publishing , a battle over typefaces is hurting <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe Systems Inc . </ENAMEX>, which sells software that controls the image produced by printers and displays . 
2596 Until recently , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>had a lock on the market for image software , but <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>' s biggest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">customer </ENAMEX>, and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft </ENAMEX>rebelled . 
2735 Now the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>are collaborating on an alternative to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>' s approach , and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say they are likely to carry <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>, the biggest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">seller </ENAMEX>of personal computers , along with them .

3122 The program is aimed at improving the quality of printed material .

3414 Meanwhile , competition between various operating systems , which control the basic functions of a computer , spells trouble for software <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>generally . 
3566 ` It creates uncertainty and usually slows down sales , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Russ Crabs </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Soundview Financial Group </ENAMEX>.

3818 He expects <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Aldus </ENAMEX>to report earnings of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">21 cents </NUMEX>a share on revenues of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 19 . 5 million </NUMEX>for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its third quarter </TIMEX>, compared with earnings of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">30 cents </NUMEX>a share on revenue of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">20 . 4 million </NUMEX>in the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - earlier </TIMEX>period . 
4024 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Aldus </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>could n't be reached for comment . 
4075 On the other hand , the battle of the bus is expected to grow increasingly irrelevant . 
4161 A bus is the data highway within a computer . 
4206 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>is backing <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>type of bus called microchannel , while the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">nine </NUMEX>other leading computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>, including <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">H - P </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq Computer Corp . </ENAMEX>, have chosen another method . 
4375 ` <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Users </ENAMEX>do n't care about the bus , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Daniel Benton </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Goldman , Sachs &amp; Co .  
4464 He said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">family </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Macintosh </ENAMEX>computers , for instance , uses <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX>different buses ` and no one seems to mind . ' 
4581 The gap between <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">winners </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">laggards </ENAMEX>will grow .

9 When the price of <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">plastics </ENAMEX>took off in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Quantum Chemical Corp . </ENAMEX>went along for the ride .

907 To a degree , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Quantum </ENAMEX>represents <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the new times </TIMEX>that have arrived for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">producers </ENAMEX>of the so - called commodity <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">plastics </ENAMEX>that pervade modern life .

6000 Until <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>had been steadily lowering its accident rate and picking up trade - group safety awards .

6229 When a <ENAMEX TYPE="PLANT">plant </ENAMEX>has just been running flat out to meet demand , calculating lost profit and thus claims under business - interruption insurance is straightforward .

9 While corn and soybean prices have slumped well below their drought - induced peaks of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>, wheat prices remain stubbornly high . 
137 And they ' re likely to stay that way for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">months </TIMEX>to come , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say . 
209 For <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>thing , even with many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">farmers </ENAMEX>planting more <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">winter </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">wheat </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>than last , tight wheat supplies are likely to support prices well into <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1990 </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say . 
379 And if rain does n't fall soon across many of the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Great Plains </ENAMEX>' wheat - growing areas , yields in the <ENAMEX TYPE="PLANT">crop </ENAMEX>now being planted could be reduced , further squeezing supplies . 
546 Also supporting prices are expectations that the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Soviet Union </ENAMEX>will place substantial buying orders over <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the next few months </TIMEX>. 
673 By <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next May 31 </TIMEX>, stocks of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">wheat </ENAMEX>to be carried over into <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the next season </TIMEX>- - before the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">winter </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">wheat </ENAMEX>now being planted is harvested - - are projected to drop to <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">443 million bushels </NUMEX>. 
857 That would be the lowest level since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the early 1970s </TIMEX>. 
911 Stocks were <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">698 million bushels </NUMEX>on <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">May 31 of this year </TIMEX>. 
969 In response to dwindling domestic supplies , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Agriculture </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Secretary </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Clayton Yeutter </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>said the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>would slightly increase the number of acres <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">farmers </ENAMEX>can plant in <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">wheat </ENAMEX>for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next year </TIMEX>and still qualify for federal support payments . 
1220 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>estimates that the new plan will boost production <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next year </TIMEX>by <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">about 66 million bushels </NUMEX>.

442 As the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1992 </TIMEX>economic integration approaches , <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:CONTINENT">Europe </ENAMEX>' s cultural <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">curators </ENAMEX>have taken to the ramparts against <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">American </ENAMEX>` cultural imperialism , ' threatening to impose quotas against such pop invaders as ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">Dallas </ENAMEX>, ' ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">Miami Vice </ENAMEX>' and ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">L . 2504 If this seems like pretty weak stuff around which to raise the protectionist barriers , it may be because these shows need all the protection they can get . 
2659 <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">European </ENAMEX>programs usually target only their own local <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">audience </ENAMEX>, and often only a small portion of that .

4765 ` The trend is pretty well established now that local programs are the most popular , with <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">American </ENAMEX>programs <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">second </NUMEX>, ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brian Wenham </ENAMEX>, a former <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">director </ENAMEX>of programs for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">British Broadcasting Corp .  
4965 ` Given a choice , everybody will watch a home - produced show . ' 
5028 But frequently there is n't much choice . 
5068 Thus , <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:CONTINENT">Europe </ENAMEX>has begun the recent crusade to produce more worthy shows of its own , programs with broader appeal . 
5181 ` We ' ve basically got to start from scratch , to train <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">writers </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">producers </ENAMEX>to make shows that other <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>will want to see , ' concedes <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Colin Young </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">head </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Britain </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">National Film Theatre School </ENAMEX>. 
5379 While some in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>contend that advertising is the bane of television , here many believe that its absence is to blame for the <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">European </ENAMEX>TV industry ' s sluggish development . 
5554 Until recently , national <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">governments </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:CONTINENT">Europe </ENAMEX>controlled most of the air time and allowed little or no advertising . 
5671 Since production costs were guaranteed , it did n't matter that a program could n't be sold abroad or put into syndication , as most <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">American </ENAMEX>programs are . 
5823 But not much money was spent on the shows , either , a situation that encouraged cheap - to - make talk and game shows , while discouraging expensive - to - produce dramas . 
5987 Now , however , commercial channels are coming to most <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">European </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">countries </ENAMEX>, and at the same time , satellite and cable technology is spreading rapidly . 
6135 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Just last week </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Greece </ENAMEX>authorized <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>commercial <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">channels </ENAMEX>for the first time ; <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Spain </ENAMEX>earlier began to allow commercial television alongside its state <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">channels </ENAMEX>. 
6294 The result is a new and huge appetite for programming . 
6351 But perhaps to the consternation of those calling for quotas , most of this void is likely to be filled with the cheapest and most plentiful programming now available - - reruns - - usually of shows made in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S .  </ENAMEX>

9 Predicting the financial results of computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>has been a tough job lately . 
91 Take <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft Corp . </ENAMEX>, the largest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">maker </ENAMEX>of personal computer software and generally considered an industry bellwether . 
210 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>stunned Wall Street with the prediction that growth in the personal computer business overall would be <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">only 10 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1990 </TIMEX>, a modest increase when compared with the sizzling expansion of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">years past </TIMEX>. 
429 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Investors </ENAMEX>- - taking this as a sign that a broad industry slump was in the offing - - reacted by selling the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s stock , which lost <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 3 . 25 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">that day </TIMEX>to close at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 52 </NUMEX>in national over - the - counter trading . 
635 But that was <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">all of three months ago </TIMEX>. 
675 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Last week </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft </ENAMEX>said it expects revenue for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its first quarter ended Sept . 30 </TIMEX>to increase <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">34 % </NUMEX>. 
774 The announcement caused the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s stock to surge <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 6 . 50 </NUMEX>to close at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 75 . 50 </NUMEX>a share . 
863 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft </ENAMEX>' s surprising strength is <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>example of the difficulty facing <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>looking for reassurances about the financial health of the computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>. 
1020 ` It ' s hard to know what to expect at this point , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Peter Rogers </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Robertson Stephens &amp; Co .  
1128 ` The industry defies characterization . ' 
1170 To illustrate , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Rogers </ENAMEX>said that of the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">14 </NUMEX>computer - related <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>he follows , <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">half </NUMEX>will report for their <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">most recent quarter </TIMEX>earnings below <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last year </TIMEX>' s results , and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">half </NUMEX>above those results . 
1366 Among those <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>expected to have a down <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">quarter </TIMEX>are <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Hewlett - Packard Co . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Amdahl Corp . </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sun Microsystems Inc . </ENAMEX>, generally solid <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">performers </ENAMEX>in the past . 
1525 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">International Business Machines Corp . </ENAMEX>also is expected to report disappointing results . 
1613 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple Computer Inc . </ENAMEX>, meanwhile , is expected to show improved earnings for the period ended <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Sept .  
1712 Another contradictory message comes from <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Businessland Inc . </ENAMEX>, a computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">retailer </ENAMEX>. 
1793 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>reported that booming sales of new personal computers from <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>had resulted in net income more than doubling for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its fourth quarter ended June 30 </TIMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 7 . 4 million </NUMEX>, or <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">23 cents </NUMEX>a share . 
2010 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">This month </TIMEX>, however , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Businessland </ENAMEX>warned <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>that results for its <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">first quarter ended Sept . 30 </TIMEX>had n't met expectations . 
2136 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>said it expects earnings of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">14 to 17 cents </NUMEX>a share , down from <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">25 cents </NUMEX>a share in the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - earlier </TIMEX>period . 
2257 While the earnings picture confuses , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">observers </ENAMEX>say the major forces expected to shape the industry in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the coming year </TIMEX>are clearer . 
2390 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Companies </ENAMEX>will continue to war over standards . 
2437 In computer publishing , a battle over typefaces is hurting <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe Systems Inc . </ENAMEX>, which sells software that controls the image produced by printers and displays . 
2596 Until recently , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>had a lock on the market for image software , but <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>' s biggest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">customer </ENAMEX>, and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Microsoft </ENAMEX>rebelled . 
2735 Now the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>are collaborating on an alternative to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>' s approach , and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say they are likely to carry <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>, the biggest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">seller </ENAMEX>of personal computers , along with them . 
2918 The short - term outlook for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>' s business , however , appears strong . 
2988 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>is beginning to ship a new software program that ' s being heralded as a boon for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">owners </ENAMEX>of low - end printers sold by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>. 
3122 The program is aimed at improving the quality of printed material . 
3189 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John Warnock </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Adobe </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chief executive officer </ENAMEX>, said the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Mountain View </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Calif . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>has been receiving <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">1 , 000 </NUMEX>calls a day about the product since it was demonstrated at a computer publishing conference <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">several weeks ago </TIMEX>. 
3414 Meanwhile , competition between various operating systems , which control the basic functions of a computer , spells trouble for software <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>generally . 
3566 ` It creates uncertainty and usually slows down sales , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Russ Crabs </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Soundview Financial Group </ENAMEX>. 
3681 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Crabs </ENAMEX>said this probably is behind the expected weak performance of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Aldus Corp . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">maker </ENAMEX>of a widely used computer publishing program . 
3818 He expects <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Aldus </ENAMEX>to report earnings of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">21 cents </NUMEX>a share on revenues of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 19 . 5 million </NUMEX>for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its third quarter </TIMEX>, compared with earnings of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">30 cents </NUMEX>a share on revenue of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">20 . 4 million </NUMEX>in the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - earlier </TIMEX>period . 
4024 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Aldus </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>could n't be reached for comment . 
4075 On the other hand , the battle of the bus is expected to grow increasingly irrelevant . 
4161 A bus is the data highway within a computer . 
4206 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>is backing <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>type of bus called microchannel , while the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">nine </NUMEX>other leading computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>, including <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">H - P </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq Computer Corp . </ENAMEX>, have chosen another method . 
4375 ` <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Users </ENAMEX>do n't care about the bus , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Daniel Benton </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Goldman , Sachs &amp; Co .  
4464 He said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">family </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Macintosh </ENAMEX>computers , for instance , uses <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX>different buses ` and no one seems to mind . ' 
4581 The gap between <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">winners </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">laggards </ENAMEX>will grow . 
4629 In personal computers , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>are expected to tighten their hold on their business .

4796 Some lagging <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">competitors </ENAMEX>even may leave the personal computer business altogether . 
4879 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Wyse Technology </ENAMEX>, for instance , is considered a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">candidate </ENAMEX>to sell its troubled <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">operation </ENAMEX>.

5268 Personal - computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>will continue to eat away at the business of more traditional computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>. 
5371 Ever - more powerful desk - top computers , designed with <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>or more microprocessors as their ` brains , ' are expected to increasingly take on functions carried out by more expensive minicomputers and mainframes . 
5580 ` The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">guys </ENAMEX>that make traditional hardware are really being obsoleted by microprocessor - based machines , ' said Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Benton </ENAMEX>. 
5702 As a result of this trend , longtime <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">powerhouses </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">H - P </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">IBM </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Digital Equipment Corp . </ENAMEX>are scrambling to counterattack with microprocessor - based systems of their own .

9 The <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">West German </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">retailer </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">ASKO Deutsche Kaufhaus AG </ENAMEX>plans to challenge the legality of a widely employed anti - takeover defense of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Netherlands </ENAMEX>. 
170 The eventual court decision could become a landmark in <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">Dutch </ENAMEX>corporate law because the lawsuit <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">ASKO </ENAMEX>plans to file would be the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>to challenge the entire principle and practice of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>issuing voting preferred shares to management - controlled trusts to dilute voting power of common <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">stockholders </ENAMEX>. 
476 Up to now only specific aspects of these defenses have been challenged , though unsuccessfully , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">ASKO </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">Dutch </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyers </ENAMEX>noted .

396 Sound familiar ?

'

3973 NOT - GUILTY PLEA :

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust Savings Bank </ENAMEX>said federal thrift <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>ordered it to suspend dividend payments on its <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>classes of preferred stock , indicating that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>' concerns about the troubled <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>have heightened .

415 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">Regulators </ENAMEX>also ordered <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>to stop buying back the preferred stock . 
491 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">David L . Paul </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chairman </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chief executive officer </ENAMEX>, criticized the federal <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Office of Thrift Supervision </ENAMEX>, which issued the directive , saying it was ` inappropriate ' and based on ` insufficient ' reasons . 
692 He said the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrift </ENAMEX>will try to get <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>to reverse the decision . 
765 The suspension of a preferred stock dividend is a serious step that signals that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>have deep concerns about an <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>' s health . 
909 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">March </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>labeled <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>a ` troubled <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>, ' largely because of its big junk - bond holdings and its operating losses . 
1045 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the same month </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Office of Thrift Supervision </ENAMEX>ordered the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>to stop paying common stock dividends until its operations were on track . 
1197 For <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the nine months ended June 30 </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>had a net loss of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 21 . 3 million </NUMEX>, compared with <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - earlier </TIMEX>net income of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 52 . 8 million </NUMEX>. 
1330 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>, which is <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Florida </ENAMEX>' s largest <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrift </ENAMEX>, holds <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of the largest junk - bond portfolios of any <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrift </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">nation </ENAMEX>. 
1450 Since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">April </TIMEX>, it has pared its high - yield bond holdings to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 890 million </NUMEX>from <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 35 billion </NUMEX>. 
1547 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Paul </ENAMEX>said <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">only about $ 150 million </NUMEX>of the current holdings are tradeable securities registered with the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Securities and Exchange Commission </ENAMEX>. 
1690 The remainder , he said , are commercial loan participations , or private placements , that are n't filed with the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">SEC </ENAMEX>and do n't have a ready market . 
1837 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>have been in a dispute over market valuations for the junk bonds . 
1927 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Office of Thrift Supervision </ENAMEX>has been hounding <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>to provide current market values for its holdings , but <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>has said it ca n't easily obtain such values because of the relative illiquidity of the bonds and lack of a ready market . 
2174 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">Regulators </ENAMEX>have become increasingly antsy about <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust ' s </ENAMEX>and other <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrifts </ENAMEX>' junk - bond holdings in light of the recent federal thrift bailout legislation and the recent deep decline in the junk - bond market . 
2382 The legislation requires <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrifts </ENAMEX>to divest themselves of junk bonds in the new , somber regulatory climate . 
2491 In <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">American Stock Exchange </ENAMEX>composite trading <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>common shares closed at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 3 </NUMEX>, down <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">12 . 5 cents </NUMEX>. 
2600 In a statement <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>, Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Paul </ENAMEX>challenged the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>' decision , saying the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrift </ENAMEX>' s operating losses and ` apparent ' junk - bond losses ` have been substantially offset by gains in other activities of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">bank </ENAMEX>. ' 
2813 He also said substantial reserves have been set aside for possible losses from the junk bonds . 
2908 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the third quarter </TIMEX>, for instance , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>added <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 22 . 5 million </NUMEX>to its general reserves .

3215 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">branch </ENAMEX>sale is the centerpiece of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>' s strategy to transform itself into a traditional <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">S &amp; L </ENAMEX>from a high - flying <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>that relied heavily on securities trading for profits , according to Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Paul </ENAMEX>. 
3425 Most <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>and thrift <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>had expected a decision on the proposed transaction , which was announced in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>, long before now . 
3560 Many interpret the delay as an indication that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>are skeptical about the proposal . 
3652 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Branches </ENAMEX>and deposits can be sold at a premium in the event federal <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulators </ENAMEX>take over an <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>.

3903 It said the sale would give it positive tangible capital of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 82 million </NUMEX>, or <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 1 . 2 % </NUMEX>of assets , from a negative <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 33 million </NUMEX>as of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Sept . 30 </TIMEX>, thus bringing <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>close to regulatory standards . 
4101 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>said the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">branch </ENAMEX>sale would also reduce the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s large amount of good will by <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 180 million </NUMEX>. 
4212 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Critics </ENAMEX>, however , say the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">branch </ENAMEX>sale will make <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>more dependent than ever on brokered deposits and junk bonds . 
4333 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Paul </ENAMEX>counters that he intends to further pare the size of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CenTrust </ENAMEX>by not renewing <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">more than $ 1 billion </NUMEX>of brokered certificates of deposit when they come due .

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Investors </ENAMEX>who bought stock with borrowed money - - that is , ` on margin ' - - may be more worried than most following <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s market drop . 
147 That ' s because their <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">brokers </ENAMEX>can require them to sell some shares or put up more cash to enhance the collateral backing their loans . 
280 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October 1987 </TIMEX>, these margin calls were thought to have contributed to the downward spiral of the stock market . 
395 Typically , a margin call occurs when the price of a stock falls below <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">75 % </NUMEX>of its original value . 
492 If the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investor </ENAMEX>does n't put up the extra cash to satisfy the call , the brokerage <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>may begin liquidating the securities . 
618 But some big brokerage <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>said they do n't expect major problems as a result of margin calls . 
714 Margin calls since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>` have been higher than usual , but reasonable , ' a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spokesman </ENAMEX>for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc . </ENAMEX>said . 
839 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Merrill Lynch &amp; Co . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>` do n't expect -LCB- margin calls -RCB- to be as big a factor as in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>' because fewer individual <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>are buying stock on margin , a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spokesman </ENAMEX>said . 
1015 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Hugo Quackenbush </ENAMEX>, senior <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">vice president </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Charles Schwab Corp . </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">San Francisco </ENAMEX>- based discount brokerage <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>, said he did n't expect any immediate problems with margin calls for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Schwab </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">customers </ENAMEX>. 
1214 He said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Schwab </ENAMEX>had increased margin requirements ` so <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">customers </ENAMEX>have more of a cushion . ' 
1302 He added : ` We learned a lesson in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>about volatility .  

9 Call it the ` we ' re too broke to fight ' defense . 
59 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Lawyers </ENAMEX>for <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">dozens </NUMEX>of insolvent savings and loan <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">associations </ENAMEX>are trying a new tack in their efforts to defuse suits filed by <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">borrowers </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">developers </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">creditors </ENAMEX>. 
224 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">thrifts </ENAMEX>' <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyers </ENAMEX>claim that the suits , numbering <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">700 to 1 , 000 </NUMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Texas </ENAMEX>alone , should be dismissed as moot because neither the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">S &amp; Ls </ENAMEX>nor the extinct <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp . </ENAMEX>has the money to pay judgments . 
450 Though the argument may have a common - sense ring to it , even the S &amp; L <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyers </ENAMEX>concede there ' s little precedent to back their position . 
586 Still , <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>federal appeals <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>has signaled it ' s willing to entertain the notion , and the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyers </ENAMEX>have renewed their arguments in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Texas </ENAMEX>and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">eight </NUMEX>other <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>where the defense is permitted under state law . 
797 The dismissal of the pending suits could go a long way toward clearing court dockets in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Texas </ENAMEX>and reducing the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">FSLIC </ENAMEX>' s massive legal bills , which topped <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 73 million </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last year </TIMEX>. 
975 The S &amp; L <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyers </ENAMEX>were encouraged <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>by an appellate - court ruling in <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>cases brought against defunct <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt Savings &amp; Loan Association </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Dallas </ENAMEX>by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">developers </ENAMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:OTHER">Valley Ranch </ENAMEX>, best known as the training <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:OTHER">center </ENAMEX>for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Dallas Cowboys </ENAMEX>football <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">team </ENAMEX>. 
1240 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt </ENAMEX>foreclosed on the <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:OTHER">ranch </ENAMEX>. 
1275 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">FSLIC </ENAMEX>argued to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Fifth U . S . Circuit Court of Appeals </ENAMEX>` that there will never be any assets with which to satisfy a judgment against <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt Savings </ENAMEX>nor any means to collect from any other <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">party </ENAMEX>, including <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">FSLIC </ENAMEX>. ' 
1508 ` If true , ' the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>wrote , ` this contention would justify dismissal of these actions on prudential grounds . ' 
1618 But the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>said it lacked enough financial information about <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">FSLIC </ENAMEX>and sent the cases back to federal district <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Dallas </ENAMEX>. 
1767 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Charles Haworth </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyer </ENAMEX>for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt </ENAMEX>, says he plans to file a brief <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this week </TIMEX>urging the district <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">judge </ENAMEX>to dismiss the suits , because <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt </ENAMEX>' s liabilities exceeded its assets by <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 2 billion </NUMEX>when federal <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">regulators </ENAMEX>closed it in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">August 1988 </TIMEX>. 
2016 ` This <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">institution </ENAMEX>is just brain dead , ' says Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Haworth </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">partner </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Dallas </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">office </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Andrews &amp; Kurth </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Houston </ENAMEX>law <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>.

2269 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Attorney </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Richard Jackson </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Dallas </ENAMEX>says a judgment for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Triland </ENAMEX>could be satisfied in ways other than a monetary award , including the reversal of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Sunbelt </ENAMEX>' s foreclosure on <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:OTHER">Valley Ranch </ENAMEX>.

9 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>plans to raise <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 175 million </NUMEX>in new cash <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Thursday </TIMEX>by selling <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 9 . 75 billion </NUMEX>of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">52 - week </TIMEX>bills and redeeming <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 9 . 58 billion </NUMEX>of maturing bills .

9 The crowded field for notebook - sized computers is about to become a lot more crowded . 
97 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq Computer Corp . </ENAMEX>' s long - awaited entry <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>into the notebook field is expected to put immediate heat on others in the market , especially <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Zenith Electronics Corp . </ENAMEX>, the current market <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">leader </ENAMEX>, and on a swarm of promising start - ups . 
335 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s series of notebooks extends a trend toward downsizing in the personal computer market . 
431 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">manufacturer </ENAMEX>already has produced a clipboard - sized computer called a notepad , and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>others have introduced even smaller ` palmtops . ' 
572 But those machines are still considered novelties , with keyboards only a munchkin could love and screens to match . 
687 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s notebooks , by contrast , may be the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>in their weight class not to skimp on features found in much bigger machines . 
815 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Analysts </ENAMEX>say they ' re faster and carry more memory than anything else of their size on the market - - and they ' re priced aggressively at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 2 , 400 to $ 5 , 000 </NUMEX>. 
968 All of this comes in a machine that weighs <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:WEIGHT">only six pounds </NUMEX>and fits comfortably into most briefcases . 
1072 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent months </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s competition , including <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Zenith </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Toshiba Corp . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Tandy Corp . </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">NEC Corp . </ENAMEX>all have introduced portables that weigh approximately the same and that are called notebooks - - perhaps misleadingly . 
1290 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>, noting that most such machines are <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">about two inches </NUMEX>thick , takes exception to the name . 
1391 ` This is n't quite a notebook - - I call it a phonebook , ' he says . 
1458 That ca n't be said of the <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 2 , 400 </NUMEX>notepad computer introduced <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a few weeks ago </TIMEX>by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">GRiD Systems Corp . </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">unit </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Tandy </ENAMEX>. 
1575 Instead of a keyboard , it features a writing surface , an electronic pen and the ability to ` read ' block printing . 
1689 At <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:WEIGHT">4 1 \/ 2 pounds </NUMEX>, it may be too ambitiously named , but it nevertheless opens up the kind of marketing possibilities that make <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>froth . 
1832 Palmtops are n't far behind . 
1860 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Atari Corp . </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Portfolio </ENAMEX>, introduced in <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:CONTINENT">Europe </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">two months ago </TIMEX>and in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>in early <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>, weighs <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:WEIGHT">less than a pound </NUMEX>, costs a mere <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 400 </NUMEX>and runs on <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">three </NUMEX>AA batteries , yet has the power to run some spreadsheets and word processing programs . 
2107 Some <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">critics </ENAMEX>, however , say its ability to run commonplace programs is restricted by a limited memory . 
2211 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Poquet Computer Corp . </ENAMEX>, meanwhile , has introduced a much more sophisticated palmtop that can run <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lotus 1 - 2 - 3 </ENAMEX>and other sophisticated software programs , but costs <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">five </NUMEX>times as much . 
2394 At stake is what <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Mike Swavely </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:CONTINENT">North America </ENAMEX>operations , calls ` the Holy Grail of the computer industry ' - - the search for ` a real computer in a package so small you can take it everywhere . ' 
2607 The market is so new , nobody knows yet how big it can be . 
2665 ` I ' ve had a lot of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>trying to sell me services to find out how big it is , ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Tom Humphries </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">director </ENAMEX>of marketing for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">GRiD </ENAMEX>. 
2798 ` Whether it ' s <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 5 billion </NUMEX>or <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 3 . 5 billion </NUMEX>, it does n't matter . 
2859 It ' s huge . ' 
2873 Consider the growth of portables , which now comprise <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">12 % </NUMEX>of all personal computer sales . 
2962 Laptops - - generally anything under <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">15 </NUMEX>pounds - - have become the fastest - growing personal computer segment , with sales doubling <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. 
3103 Responding to that demand , however , has led to a variety of compromises . 
3176 Making computers smaller often means sacrificing memory . 
3233 It also has precluded use of the faster , more powerful microprocessors found in increasing numbers of desktop machines . 
3353 Size and weight considerations also have limited screen displays . 
3421 The competitive sniping can get pretty petty at times . 
3476 A <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Poquet </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spokesman </ENAMEX>, for example , criticizes the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Atari </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Portfolio </ENAMEX>because it requires <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">three </NUMEX>batteries while the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Poquet </ENAMEX>needs <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">only two </NUMEX>. 
3609 Both palmtops are dismissed by notebook <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>, who argue that they ' re too small - - a problem <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Poquet </ENAMEX>also encountered in focus <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">groups </ENAMEX>, admits <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Gerry Purdy </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">director </ENAMEX>of marketing . 
3787 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Poquet </ENAMEX>, trying to avoid the ` gadget ' label , responded with the tag line , ` The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Poquet </ENAMEX>PC - - a Very Big Computer . ' 
3902 Despite the sniping , few question the inevitability of the move to small machines that do n't make compromises . 
4013 Toward that end , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">experts </ENAMEX>say the real battle will take place between center - stage <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">players </ENAMEX>like <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Toshiba </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Zenith </ENAMEX>and now <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>. 
4142 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s new machines are considered a direct threat to start - up <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>like <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Dynabook Inc . </ENAMEX>, which introduced in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">June </TIMEX>a computer that , like <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s , uses an <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Intel </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">286 </ENAMEX>microprocessor and has a hard disk drive . 
4350 But the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Dynabook </ENAMEX>product is twice as heavy and costs more than <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s .

S . </ENAMEX>laptop market but recently agreed to sell its computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">business </ENAMEX>to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Cie . des Machines Bull </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">French </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>- owned computer <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">maker </ENAMEX>.

4853 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Rod Canion </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chief executive officer </ENAMEX>, notes pointedly that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Zenith </ENAMEX>' s <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 2 , 000 </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">MinisPort </ENAMEX>uses an ` unconventional ' <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">two - inch </NUMEX>floppy disk , whereas <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s new machines use the more common <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">3 1 \/ 2 - inch </NUMEX>disk . 
5074 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John P . Frank </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Zenith Data Systems </ENAMEX>, simply shrugs off such criticism , noting that <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">3 1 \/ 2 - inch </NUMEX>floppies were also ` unconventional ' when they first replaced <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">five - inch </NUMEX>disks .

5821 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Compaq </ENAMEX>' s machines include the <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">3 1 \/ 2 - inch </NUMEX>floppy disk drive , a backlit screen that is <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:1D">only 1 \/ 4 - inch </NUMEX>thick and an internal expansion slot for a modem - - in other words , almost all the capabilities of a typical office machine .

9 The oil industry ' s middling profits could persist through the rest of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the year </TIMEX>. 
91 Major oil <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the next few days </TIMEX>are expected to report much less robust earnings than they did for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the third quarter a year ago </TIMEX>, largely reflecting deteriorating chemical prices and gasoline profitability . 
306 The gasoline picture may improve <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this quarter </TIMEX>, but <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">chemicals </ENAMEX>are likely to remain weak , industry <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say , reducing chances that profits could equal their <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - earlier </TIMEX>performance . 
508 The industry is ` seeing a softening somewhat in volume and certainly in price in <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">petrochemicals </ENAMEX>, ' <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Glenn Cox </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Phillips Petroleum Co . </ENAMEX>, said in an interview .

785 He did n't forecast <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Phillips </ENAMEX>' s results . 
826 But securities <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Phillips </ENAMEX>will be among the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>hard - hit by weak chemical prices and will probably post a drop in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">third - quarter </TIMEX>earnings . 
981 So , too , many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>predict , will <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Exxon Corp . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Chevron Corp . </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Amoco Corp .  
1063 Typical is what happened to the price of <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">ethylene </ENAMEX>, a major commodity <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">chemical </ENAMEX>produced in vast amounts by many oil <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>. 
1189 It has plunged <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">13 % </NUMEX>since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">around 26 cents </NUMEX>a pound . 
1247 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">A year ago </TIMEX>ethylene sold for <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">33 cents </NUMEX>, peaking at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about 34 cents </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last December </TIMEX>. 
1329 A big reason for the chemical price retreat is overexpansion . 
1391 Beginning in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">mid - 1987 </TIMEX>, prices began accelerating as a growing <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>economy and the weak dollar spurred demand . 
1502 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Companies </ENAMEX>added capacity furiously . 
1538 Now , greatly increased supplies are on the market , while the dollar is stronger , and domestic economic growth is slower . 
1661 Third - quarter profits from <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">gasoline </ENAMEX>were weaker . 
1710 ` Refining margins were so good in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the third quarter of last year </TIMEX>and generally not very good <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>, ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">William Randol </ENAMEX>, a securities <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">First Boston Corp .  
1881 Oil company <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">refineries </ENAMEX>ran flat out to prepare for a robust holiday driving season in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>and <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">August </TIMEX>that did n't materialize . 
2008 The excess supply pushed gasoline prices down in that period . 
2070 In addition , crude oil prices were up some from <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a year earlier </TIMEX>, further pressuring profitability . 
2170 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Refiners </ENAMEX>say margins picked up in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>, and many industry <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>believe gasoline profits will rebound <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this quarter </TIMEX>, though still not to the level of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 ' s fourth quarter </TIMEX>. 
2351 During <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1988 second half </TIMEX>, many <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>posted record gasoline and chemical profits . 
2442 Crude oil production may turn out to be the most surprising element of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>' earnings <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. 
2544 Prices - - averaging roughly <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 2 </NUMEX>a barrel higher in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the third quarter </TIMEX>than <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a year earlier </TIMEX>- - have stayed well above most <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>' expectations . 
2688 Demand has been much stronger than anticipated , and it typically accelerates in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the fourth quarter </TIMEX>. 
2788 ` We could see higher oil prices <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>, ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bryan Jacoboski </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">PaineWebber Inc .  
2887 That will translate into sharply higher production profits , particularly compared with <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last year </TIMEX>when oil prices steadily fell to below <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 13 </NUMEX>a barrel in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the fourth quarter </TIMEX>. 
3061 While oil prices have been better than expected , natural gas prices have been worse . 
3146 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the third quarter </TIMEX>, they averaged <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 5 % </NUMEX>less than they were in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>. 
3220 The main reason remains weather . 
3253 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Last summer </TIMEX>was notable for a heat wave and drought that caused <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">utilities </ENAMEX>to burn more natural <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">gas </ENAMEX>to feed increased electrical demand from air conditioning use . 
3415 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">This summer </TIMEX>, on the other hand , had milder weather than usual . 
3480 ` We ' ve been very disappointed in the performance of natural gas prices , ' said Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Cox </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Phillips </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>. 
3589 ` The lagging gas price is not going to assist <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">fourth quarter </TIMEX>performance as many had expected . ' 
3687 Going into <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the fourth quarter </TIMEX>, natural gas prices are anywhere from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">8 % to 17 % </NUMEX>lower than <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a year earlier </TIMEX>. 
3792 For instance , natural <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">gas </ENAMEX>currently produced along the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Gulf Coast </ENAMEX>is selling on the spot market for <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">around $ 1 . 47 </NUMEX>a <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">thousand cubic feet </NUMEX>, down <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">13 % </NUMEX>from <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 69 </NUMEX>a <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">thousand cubic feet </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a year ago </TIMEX>.

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>, in a move to reduce the costs of wooing new <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">subscribers </ENAMEX>, is lowering its circulation guarantee to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">advertisers </ENAMEX>for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the second consecutive year </TIMEX>, increasing its subscription rates and cutting back on merchandise giveaways . 
246 In an announcement to its <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">staff </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last week </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time Warner Inc . </ENAMEX>' s <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">weekly </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>will ` dramatically de - emphasize ' its use of electronic giveaways such as telephones in television subscription drives ; cut the circulation it guarantees <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">advertisers </ENAMEX>by <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">300 , 000 </NUMEX>, to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four million </NUMEX>; and increase the cost of its <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">annual </TIMEX>subscription rate by <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 4 to $ 55 </NUMEX>. 
619 In a related development , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">news - weekly </ENAMEX>, for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">the fourth year </TIMEX>in a row , said it wo n't increase its advertising rates in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1990 </TIMEX>; a full , <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX>- color page in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>costs <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 120 , 000 </NUMEX>. 
808 However , because the guaranteed circulation base is being lowered , ad rates will be effectively <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">7 . 5 % </NUMEX>higher per <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">subscriber </ENAMEX>, according to <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Richard Heinemann </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>associate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">publisher </ENAMEX>. 
992 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>is following the course of some other mass - circulation <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazines </ENAMEX>that in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent years </TIMEX>have challenged the publishing myth that maintaining artificially high , and expensive , circulations is the way to draw <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">advertisers </ENAMEX>. 
1215 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent years </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Reader ' s Digest </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">New York Times Co . </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">McCall ' s </ENAMEX>, and most recently <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">News Corp . </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">TV Guide </ENAMEX>, have cut their massive circulation rate bases to eliminate marginal circulation and hold down rates for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">advertisers </ENAMEX>. 
1442 Deep discounts in subscriptions and offers of free clock radios and watches have become accepted forms of attracting new <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">subscribers </ENAMEX>in the hyper - competitive world of magazine <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">news - weeklies </ENAMEX>. 
1633 But <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>, as part of the more cost - conscious <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time Warner </ENAMEX>, wants to wean itself away from expensive gimmicks . 
1742 Besides , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>think selling a news <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>with a clock radio is tacky . 
1826 ` Giveaways just give <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>the wrong image , ' said Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Heinemann </ENAMEX>. 
1892 ` That perception takes the focus off the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>. ' 
1946 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>magazine <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>predictably paint the circulation cut as a show of strength and actually a benefit to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">advertisers </ENAMEX>. 
2070 ` What we are doing is screening out the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">readers </ENAMEX>who are only casually related to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>and do n't really read it , ' said Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Heinemann </ENAMEX>. 
2211 ` We are trying to create quality and involvement . ' 
2264 However , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>used the same explanation when in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October 1988 </TIMEX>the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>cut its guaranteed circulation from <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">4 . 6 million </NUMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">4 . 3 million </NUMEX>. 
2413 And <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>' s paid circulation , according to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Audit Bureau of Circulations </ENAMEX>, dropped <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">7 . 3 % </NUMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">4 , 393 , 237 </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the six months ended June 30 , 1989 </TIMEX>. 
2552 Still , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>' s move is being received well , once again . 
2607 ` It ' s terrific for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">advertisers </ENAMEX>to know the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">reader </ENAMEX>will be paying more , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Michael Drexler </ENAMEX>, national media <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">director </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Bozell Inc . </ENAMEX>ad <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">agency </ENAMEX>. 
2751 ` A few drops in circulation are of no consequence . 
2802 It ' s not a show of weakness ; they are improving the quality of circulation while insuring their profits . ' 
2910 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Heinemann </ENAMEX>said the changes represent a new focus in the magazine industry : a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazine </ENAMEX>' s net revenue per <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">subscriber </ENAMEX>, or the actual revenue from <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">subscribers </ENAMEX>after discounts and the cost of premiums have been stripped away . 
3135 ` The question is how much are we getting from each <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">reader </ENAMEX>, ' said Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Heinemann </ENAMEX>. 
3217 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Time </ENAMEX>' s rivals <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">news - weeklies </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Washington Post Co . </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Newsweek </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">U . S . News &amp; World Report </ENAMEX>, are less reliant on electronic giveaways , and in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent years </TIMEX>both have been increasing their circulation rate bases . 
3426 Both <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">magazines </ENAMEX>are expected to announce their ad rates and circulation levels for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1990 </TIMEX>within <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">a month </TIMEX>.  

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Inland Steel Industries Inc . </ENAMEX>expects to report that <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">third - quarter </TIMEX>earnings dropped <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">more than 50 % </NUMEX>from <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the previous quarter </TIMEX>as a result of reduced sales volume and increased costs .

569 At the same time , the integrated - steel business was hurt by continued increases in materials costs and repair and maintenance expenses , as well as higher labor costs under its new contract .
