9 Proposals for government - operated ` national service , ' like <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">influenza </ENAMEX>, flare up from time to time , depress the resistance of the body politic , run their course , and seem to disappear , only to mutate and afflict public life anew . 
239 The disease metaphor comes to mind , of course , not as an aspersion on the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">advocates </ENAMEX>of national service . 
344 Rather , it is born of frustration with having to combat constantly changing strains of a statist idea that one thought had been eliminated in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the early 1970s </TIMEX>, along with <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">smallpox </ENAMEX>. 
526 It is back with us again , in the form of legislation to pay <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">volunteers </ENAMEX>under a ` National and Community Service Act , ' a proposal with a serious shot at congressional passage <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this fall </TIMEX>. 
712 Why does the national - service <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">virus </ENAMEX>keep coming back ? 
766 Perhaps it is because utopian nostalgia evokes both military experience and the social gospel . 
861 If only we could get <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">America </ENAMEX>' s wastrel <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">youth </ENAMEX>into at least a psychic uniform we might be able to teach self - discipline again and revive the spirit of giving . 
1021 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">A quarter of a century ago </TIMEX>national service was promoted as a way of curing the manifest inequities of the draft - - by , of all things , expanding the draft . 
1177 Those of us who resisted the idea then suspect <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>that an obligation of government service for all young <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>is still the true long - term aim of many national - service <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">backers </ENAMEX>, despite their protests that present plans contain no coercion . 
1423 Choice of the volunteer military in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1970s </TIMEX>seemed to doom national service as much as the draft . 
1523 But the <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">virus </ENAMEX>was kept alive in sociology <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">departments </ENAMEX>until <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a couple of years ago </TIMEX>, when it again was let loose . 
1635 This time it attempted to invade <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>connected problems , the rising cost of higher education and the rising expense to the federal <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>of educational grants and loans . 
1810 Why not keep and even expand the loans and grants , the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">advocates </ENAMEX>reasoned , but require some form of service from each <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">recipient </ENAMEX>? 
1939 Military service , moreover , could be a national - service option . 
2005 Thus , undoubtedly it was hoped that the new strain of national service would prove contagious , infecting patriotic <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">conservatives </ENAMEX>, pay - as - you - go <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">moderates </ENAMEX>, and idealistic <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">liberals </ENAMEX>. 
2185 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:POLITICAL">Democratic Leadership Council </ENAMEX>, a centrist <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">group </ENAMEX>sponsoring the plan , surely thought it might help the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:POLITICAL">party </ENAMEX>to attract support , especially among college <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>and their <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">parents </ENAMEX>. 
2370 A provision allowing grants to be applied to <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>- home purchases was added to appeal to those who had had enough of schooling . 
2500 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:POLITICAL">DLC </ENAMEX>plan envisaged ` <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">volunteers </ENAMEX>' planting <ENAMEX TYPE="PLANT">trees </ENAMEX>, emptying bedpans , tutoring <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">children </ENAMEX>, and assisting <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">librarians </ENAMEX>for <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 100 </NUMEX>a week , tax free , plus medical care . 
2660 With a tax - free <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 10 , 000 </NUMEX>voucher payment at <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the end of each year </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">volunteers </ENAMEX>would be making a wage comparable to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 17 , 500 </NUMEX>a year . 
2793 Mind you , most of ` the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">volunteers </ENAMEX>' would be unskilled <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">17 - to 18 - year - olds </TIMEX>, some not even high school <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">graduates </ENAMEX>, and many saving money by living at <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">home </ENAMEX>. 
2946 They would be doing better financially under national service than many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">taxpayers </ENAMEX>working at the same kinds of jobs and perhaps supporting <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">families </ENAMEX>. 
3097 As it happened , political resistance developed among educational and minority interests that count on the present education grant system , so the national - service <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">devotees </ENAMEX>decided to abandon the supposedly crucial principle of ` give in order to get . ' 
3347 Opposition to national service from the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Pentagon </ENAMEX>, which wants to protect its own recruitment process , also led to the military - service option being dropped . 
3506 Clearly , a new rationale for national service had to be cooked up . 
3573 What better place to turn than <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Edward Kennedy </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Labor Committee </ENAMEX>, that great stove of government expansionism , where many a stagnant pot of <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">porridge </ENAMEX>is kept on the back burner until it can be brought forward and presented as nouvelle <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">cuisine </ENAMEX>? 
3822 In this case , the new recipe for national service called for throwing many assorted legislative leftovers into <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>kettle : a demonstration project for educational aid -LRB- particularly satisfying to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:POLITICAL">DLC </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Sam Nunn </ENAMEX>-RRB- , a similar demonstration program for youth conservation -LRB- a la <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Chris Dodd </ENAMEX>-RRB- , a competitive grants program to <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>to spark youth and senior citizen volunteer projects -LRB- a <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Kennedy </ENAMEX>specialty -RRB- , a community service work - study program for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>-LRB- pleasing to the palate of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Dale Bumpers </ENAMEX>, among others -RRB- , plus engorgement of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">VISTA </ENAMEX>volunteer program and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Retired Senior Volunteer </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Foster Grandparent </ENAMEX>, and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Senior Companion </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">programs </ENAMEX>. 
4485 Before the menu is printed , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>may add more ingredients , also changing the initial price , now posted at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">some $ 330 million </NUMEX>. 
4617 It is widely known that ` too many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">cooks </ENAMEX>spoil the <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:FOOD">broth </ENAMEX>, ' but that wisdom does not necessarily reflect the view of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">cooks </ENAMEX>, especially if they are <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">senators </ENAMEX>. 
4776 The ` omnibus ' bill coming out of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX>may be unwholesome glop , but the assorted <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chefs </ENAMEX>are happy and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">restaurant </ENAMEX>is pushing the dish very hard . 
4926 The aroma of patronage is in the air . 
4966 Is the voluntary sector so weak that it needs such unsolicited assistance ? 
5041 On the contrary , it is as robust as ever . 
5083 According to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Gallup Poll </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">American </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">adults </ENAMEX>contribute an average of <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">two hours </TIMEX>a week of service , while financial contributions to charity in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1980s </TIMEX>have risen <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">30 % </NUMEX>-LRB- adjusted for inflation -RRB- . 
5280 Even if <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>does see various ` unmet needs , ' national service is not the way to meet them . 
5377 If we want to support <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>, we might adopt the idea used in other <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">countries </ENAMEX>of offering more scholarships based on something called ` scholarship , ' rather than on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>' s idea of ` service . ' 
5579 Or we might provide a tax credit for working <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>. 
5634 What we do not need to do is start a war , and then try to justify it by creating a <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">GI Bill </ENAMEX>. 
5728 To the extent we lack manpower to staff menial jobs in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:HOSPITAL">hospitals </ENAMEX>, for example , we should raise pay , pursue labor - saving technology , or allow more legal immigration , rather than overpay high school <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">graduates </ENAMEX>as short - term <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">workers </ENAMEX>and cause resentment among permanent <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">workers </ENAMEX>paid lesser amounts to do the same jobs . 
6045 Will national service , in the current highly politicized and opportunistic form exert enough appeal to get adopted ? 
6161 Not necessarily . 
6178 Polls show wide , generalized support for some vague concept of service , but the bill now under discussion lacks any passionate public backing . 
6321 Nonetheless , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Democrats </ENAMEX>are organizing a roll of supporting ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">associations </ENAMEX>, ' ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">societies </ENAMEX>' and ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">councils </ENAMEX>, ' some of which may hope to receive the paid ` <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">volunteers </ENAMEX>. ' 
6490 So far , the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>seems ill - disposed to substitute any of the omnibus for his own free - standing proposal to endow a ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Points of Light </ENAMEX>' <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">foundation </ENAMEX>with <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 25 million </NUMEX>to inform <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">citizens </ENAMEX>of all ages and exhort them to genuine volunteerism . 
6730 However , even this admirable plan could become objectionable if the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">White House </ENAMEX>gives in to congressional <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Democratic </ENAMEX>pressure to add to the scope of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>' s initiative or to involve the independent <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">foundation </ENAMEX>in ` brokering ' federal funds for volunteer projects . 
7002 There ' s no need for such concessions . 
7040 The omnibus can be defeated , the virus controlled , and real service protected . 
7119 National service , the utopian idea , still wo n't go away then , of course , but <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">the millions </NUMEX>of knee - socked <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">youth </ENAMEX>performing works of ` civic content ' will be mobilized only in the imagination of their <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">progenitors </ENAMEX>. 
7332 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Chapman </ENAMEX>is a fellow at the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Indianapolis </ENAMEX>- based <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Hudson Institute </ENAMEX>. 
7400 This article is adapted from remarks at a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Hoover Institution </ENAMEX>conference on national service , in which Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Szanton </ENAMEX>also participated .  

9 A federal appeals <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">San Francisco </ENAMEX>ruled that <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">shareholders </ENAMEX>ca n't hold corporate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>liable for false sales projections on new products if the news media concurrently revealed substantial information about the product ' s flaws . 
249 The ruling stems from a <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1984 </TIMEX>suit filed by <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">shareholders </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple Computer Inc . </ENAMEX>, claiming that company <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>misled <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>about the expected success of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lisa </ENAMEX>computer , introduced in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1983 </TIMEX>. 
449 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Lawyers </ENAMEX>specializing in shareholder suits said they are concerned that use of the ` press defense ' by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">corporations </ENAMEX>may become popular as a result of the ruling . 
611 According to the suit , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>created public excitement by touting <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lisa </ENAMEX>as an office computer that would revolutionize the workplace and be extremely successful in its <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">first year </TIMEX>. 
800 The <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">plaintiffs </ENAMEX>also alleged that prior to the fanfare , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>circulated internal memos indicating problems with <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lisa </ENAMEX>. 
926 The suit claimed <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>' s stock climbed to a high of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 63 . 50 </NUMEX>a share on the basis of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s optimistic forecasts . 
1045 But when the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>revealed <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lisa </ENAMEX>' s poor sales late in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1983 </TIMEX>, the stock plummeted to a low of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 17 . 37 </NUMEX>a share , according to the suit . 
1178 The <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">shareholders </ENAMEX>claimed <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">more than $ 150 million </NUMEX>in losses . 
1239 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">San Francisco </ENAMEX>district <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>dismissed the case largely because newspaper reports had sufficiently counterbalanced the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s statements by alerting <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">consumers </ENAMEX>to <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lisa </ENAMEX>' s problems . 
1436 Late <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>, the appeals <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>agreed that most of the case should be dismissed . 
1521 However , it gave the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">shareholders </ENAMEX>the right to pursue a small portion of their claim that pertains to <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Lisa </ENAMEX>' s disk drive , known as <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Twiggy </ENAMEX>. 
1659 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>ruled that the news <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">media </ENAMEX>did n't reveal <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Twiggy </ENAMEX>' s problems at the time . 
1742 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Lawyers </ENAMEX>are worried about the ruling ' s implication in other shareholder suits but pointed out that the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>stressed that the ruling should be regarded as very specific to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Apple </ENAMEX>case . 
1933 ` The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>was careful to say that the adverse information appeared in the very same articles and received the same attention as the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s statements , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Patrick Grannon </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Los Angeles </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyer </ENAMEX>at the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Greenfield &amp; Chimicles </ENAMEX>, which was n't involved in the case . 
2206 ` The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>is saying that the adverse facts have to be transferred to the market with equal intensity and credibility as the statements of corporate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">insiders </ENAMEX>. ' 
2368 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Shareholders </ENAMEX>' <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">attorneys </ENAMEX>at the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Milberg , Weiss , Bershad , Specthrie &amp; Lerach </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last week </TIMEX>petitioned for a rehearing of the case . 
2510 They wrote : ` The opinion establishes a new rule of immunity - - that if a wide variety of opinions on a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s business are publicly reported , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>can say anything without fear of securities liability . '

3038 But the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">jury </ENAMEX>awarded the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">USFL </ENAMEX><NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">only $ 1 </NUMEX>in damages , trebled because of the antitrust claims .

Court of Appeals </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>upheld a <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 5 . 5 million </NUMEX>award of attorneys fees to the defunct <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">league </ENAMEX>. 
3249 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Harvey D . Myerson </ENAMEX>, of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Myerson &amp; Kuhn </ENAMEX>, then of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Finley , Kumble , Wagner , Heine , Underberg , Manley , Myerson &amp; Casey </ENAMEX>, was the lead trial <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyer </ENAMEX>, and his new <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>pursued the application appeal .

3576 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Myerson &amp; Kuhn </ENAMEX>will get <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 260 , 000 </NUMEX>for the costs of pressing the application . 
3660 The federal appeals <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>held that the nominal damages and the failure to prove all claims did n't exclude the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">USFL </ENAMEX>from being reimbursed . 
3799 Antitrust laws provide that injured <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">parties </ENAMEX>may be reimbursed for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawyers </ENAMEX>' fees . 
3882 But <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Shepard Goldfein </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">attorney </ENAMEX>for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">NFL </ENAMEX>, says his <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">client </ENAMEX>will consider asking for another hearing or appealing to the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Supreme Court </ENAMEX>. 
4026 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Goldfein </ENAMEX>, of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Skadden , Arps , Slate , Meagher &amp; Flom </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>, says the ruling is wrong and the fee award is excessive because the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">USFL </ENAMEX>lost its major claims , including its contention that the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">NFL </ENAMEX>restrained trade through television contracts . 
4276 ` The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">USFL </ENAMEX>was not the prevailing <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">party </ENAMEX>, ' Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Goldfein </ENAMEX>insists . 
4341 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">HOUSTON </ENAMEX>- <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">CALGARY </ENAMEX>ALLIANCE : 
4367 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Fulbright &amp; Jaworski </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Houston </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Fenerty , Robertson , Fraser &amp; Hatch </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Calgary </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Alberta </ENAMEX>, are affiliating to help serve their energy - industry <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">clients </ENAMEX>. 
4520 The affiliation is believed to be the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>such cross - border arrangement among major law <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>.

C . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">office </ENAMEX>will play a key role as the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>work together on regulatory issues , particularly <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">natural - gas </ENAMEX>exports , for their <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">clients </ENAMEX>.

5357 IN WHAT MAY SIGNAL a turnaround for <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">asbestos </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">manufacturers </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">W . R . Grace &amp; Co . </ENAMEX>won a <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">3 1 \/ 2 - week </TIMEX>trial in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Pittsburgh </ENAMEX>over whether it should be required to remove asbestos fireproofing from a local <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">high school </ENAMEX>. 
5564 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">Mount Lebanon High School </ENAMEX>, near <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Pittsburgh </ENAMEX>, sought <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 21 million </NUMEX>in compensatory damages from <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Grace </ENAMEX>, arguing that the <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">asbestos </ENAMEX>, which can cause respiratory diseases and lung <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">cancer </ENAMEX>, posed a risk to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>. 
5770 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Grace </ENAMEX>successfully contended that removing the fire <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">retardant </ENAMEX>would pose a greater health risk than leaving it alone . 
5888 A <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spokesman </ENAMEX>for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>said the verdict is thought to be the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>in favor of an <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">asbestos </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">manufacturer </ENAMEX>where the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">plaintiff </ENAMEX>was a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">school </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">asbestos </ENAMEX>in question was used for fireproofing .

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">CityFed Financial Corp . </ENAMEX>said it expects to report a loss of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">at least $ 125 million to $ 150 million </NUMEX>for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the third quarter </TIMEX>.

9 The <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>major event <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">this morning </TIMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>stock and futures trading may be a pause at the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Chicago Mercantile Exchange </ENAMEX>. 
131 Under a reform arising from the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash , trading in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Merc </ENAMEX>' s stock - index futures will break for <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">10 minutes </TIMEX>if the contract opens and stays <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">five </NUMEX>points from <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s close , a move equal to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">40 </NUMEX>points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average . 
371 The aim of the interruption would be to ease the opening of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">New York Stock Exchange </ENAMEX>, which would be hammered by such a volatile move on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Merc </ENAMEX>. 
523 That <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">early - morning </TIMEX>breather is just <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of a number of safeguards adopted after the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash . 
619 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>also added computer capacity to handle huge surges in trading volume . 
703 Several of those post - crash changes kicked in during <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">one - hour </TIMEX>collapse and worked as expected , even though they did n't prevent a stunning plunge . 
858 But the major ` circuit breakers ' have yet to be evaluated . 
917 A deeper market plunge <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>could give them their <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>test . 
982 A further slide also would resurrect debate over a host of other , more sweeping changes proposed - - but not implemented - - after the last crash . 
1127 Most notably , several of the regulatory steps recommended by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Brady Task Force </ENAMEX>, which analyzed the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash , would be revived - - especially because that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">group </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chairman </ENAMEX>is now the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">secretary </ENAMEX>. 
1333 The most controversial of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brady </ENAMEX>recommendations involved establishing a single overarching <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">regulator </ENAMEX>to handle crucial cross - market questions , such as setting consistent margin requirements for the stock and futures markets . 
1564 But for the moment , attention focuses on the reforms that were put into place , and market <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">regulators </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">participants </ENAMEX>said the circuit breakers worked as intended . 
1728 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Merc </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>expressed satisfaction with the results of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>limits imposed on of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Merc </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Standard &amp; Poor </ENAMEX>' s <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">500 </NUMEX>contract , as well as ` hot - line ' communications among <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">exchanges </ENAMEX>. 
1922 Those pauses - - <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">from 2 : 07 p . m . to 2 : 30 p . m . CDT </TIMEX>and <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">from 2 : 45 p . m . until the close of trading a half - hour later </TIMEX>- - forced <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>to buy and sell contracts at prices at or higher than their frozen levels . 
2129 During the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>halt , after the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX>index had fallen <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">12 </NUMEX>points , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Big Board </ENAMEX>' s ` <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT:OTHER">Sidecar </ENAMEX>' computer program automatically was triggered . 
2266 That system is designed to separate computer - generated program trades from all other trades to help exchange <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>resolve order imbalances in individual stocks . 
2434 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Merc </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">broker </ENAMEX>compared the action in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX>pit during the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>freezes to a fire at a well - drilled <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">school </ENAMEX>. 
2544 ` You do n't want the fire but you know what to do , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Howard Dubnow </ENAMEX>, an independent floor <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">broker </ENAMEX>and a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Merc </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">governor </ENAMEX>. 
2664 ` There was no panic . 
2685 The system worked the way we devised it to work . ' 
2737 After reopening for <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">about 15 minutes </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX>index tumbled to its <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">30 </NUMEX>- point limit and the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">second </NUMEX>freeze went into effect . 
2859 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Traders </ENAMEX>then spent <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">the last half - hour </TIMEX>` watching to see if the Dow would drop <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">250 </NUMEX>points , ' Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Dubnow </ENAMEX>added , referring to the level at which the stock market itself would have closed for <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">an hour </TIMEX>. 
3054 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">observer </ENAMEX>estimated that <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">80 % to 90 % </NUMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>` were just standing around watching . ' 
3152 But the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">250 </NUMEX>- point circuit breaker never had to kick in , and freezes on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Chicago Board of Trade </ENAMEX>' s Major Market Index also were n't triggered . 
3295 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">MMI </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX><NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">500 </NUMEX>are the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>major indexes used by program <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>to run their computerized trading strategies . 
3415 The programs are considered by many to be a major cause of the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash . 
3492 The process of post - crash reforms began with calls to remake the markets and wound up <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">a year later </TIMEX>with a series of rather technical adjustments . 
3640 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October 1987 </TIMEX>, just after the market drop , <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Washington </ENAMEX>was awash in talk of sweeping changes in the way the financial markets are structured and regulated . 
3797 Over <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the next year </TIMEX>that grand agenda was whittled down to a series of steps to soften big stock drops by interrupting trading to give market <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">players </ENAMEX>time to pause and reconsider positions . 
3986 In addition , limits were placed on computer - driven trading , and steps were taken to better link the stock and futures markets . 
4113 Few changes were made in the way the markets are regulated . 
4175 At the outset the prime target was program trading , which was much discussed but little understood on <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Capitol Hill </ENAMEX>. 
4291 There were also calls to strip the stock markets of ` derivative ' products , such as stock - index futures and options , which <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Judge </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Stanley Sporkin </ENAMEX>, for example , likened to ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ANIMAL">barnacles </ENAMEX>attached to the basic market . ' 
4510 And there was much criticism of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">New York Stock Exchange </ENAMEX>' s system of having stock trades flow through <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">specialists </ENAMEX>, or market <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>. 
4648 When the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Brady Task Force </ENAMEX>' s powerful analysis of the crash was released in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">January 1988 </TIMEX>, it immediately reshaped the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">reformers </ENAMEX>' agenda . 
4784 Arguing that the separate financial <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">marketplaces </ENAMEX>acted as <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>, and concluding that the crash had ` raised the possibility of a full - scale financial system breakdown , ' the presidential <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">task force </ENAMEX>called for establishing a super - <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">regulator </ENAMEX>to oversee the markets , to make margins consistent across markets , to unify clearing systems and to install circuit breakers . 
5148 Only the last of those recommendations ever was implemented . 
5209 The <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Reagan </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">White House </ENAMEX>held the <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brady </ENAMEX>recommendations at arm ' s length and named a <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">second </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">panel </ENAMEX>- - the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Working Group on the Financial Markets </ENAMEX>- - to review its analysis and those of other crash studies . 
5410 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">May 1988 </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Working Group </ENAMEX>, made up of representatives from the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Reserve </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Securities and Exchange Commission </ENAMEX>, and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Commodity Futures Trading Commission </ENAMEX>, finally endorsed only circuit breakers . 
5637 After <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">several more months </TIMEX>of arguments among various stock <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">exchanges </ENAMEX>and futures markets , circuit breakers were set in place , with the most notable suspending trading after <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">250 </NUMEX>and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">400 </NUMEX>point drops in the Dow Jones Industrial Average . 
5871 Privately , some free <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">marketeers </ENAMEX>dismissed such mechanisms as sops to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">interventionists </ENAMEX>. 
5958 After all , this free - market argument went , the Dow only dropped <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">more than 250 </NUMEX>points once <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">this century </TIMEX>. 
6064 ` Circuit breakers ' set to soften big drops : 
6110 - - If <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">S &amp; P </ENAMEX>futures fall <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">5 </NUMEX>points at opening , contract trading pauses for <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">10 minutes </TIMEX>.

625 Under these deals , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">RTC </ENAMEX>sells just the deposits and the healthy assets . 
700 These ` clean - bank ' transactions leave the bulk of bad assets , mostly real estate , with the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>, to be sold later . 
821 In these <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX>, for instance , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">RTC </ENAMEX>is stuck with <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 4 . 51 billion </NUMEX>in bad assets . 
901 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">Acquirers </ENAMEX>paid premiums ranging from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">1 . 5 % to 3 . 7 % </NUMEX>for the deposits and branch <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">systems </ENAMEX>, roughly in line with what <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>were expecting . 
1041 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">buyers </ENAMEX>will also be locked into deposit rates for just <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">two weeks </TIMEX>, as has been the case with previous deals .

9 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>' s steep rise in producer prices shows that inflation still persists , and the pessimism over interest rates caused by the new price data contributed to the stock market ' s plunge <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>. 
206 After falling for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">three consecutive months </TIMEX>, the producer price index for finished goods shot up <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 9 % </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Labor Department </ENAMEX>reported <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>, as energy prices jumped after tumbling through <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the summer </TIMEX>. 
418 Although the report , which was released before the stock market opened , did n't trigger the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">190 . 58 </NUMEX>- point drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>said it did play a role in the market ' s decline . 
622 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Analysts </ENAMEX>immediately viewed the price data , the grimmest inflation news in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">months </TIMEX>, as evidence that the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Reserve </ENAMEX>was unlikely to allow interest rates to fall as many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>had hoped . 
818 Further fueling the belief that pressures in the economy were sufficient to keep the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Fed </ENAMEX>from easing credit , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Commerce Department </ENAMEX>reported <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>that retail sales grew <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 5 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>, to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 145 . 21 billion </NUMEX>. 
1029 That rise came on top of a <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 7 % </NUMEX>gain in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">August </TIMEX>, and suggested there is still healthy consumer demand in the economy . 
1148 ` I think the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>report , combined with the actions of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Fed </ENAMEX>, weakened the belief that there was going to be an imminent easing of monetary policy , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Robert Dederick </ENAMEX>, chief <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">economist </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Northern Trust Co . </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Chicago </ENAMEX>. 
1375 But <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">economists </ENAMEX>were divided over the extent of the inflation threat signaled by the new numbers . 
1474 ` The overall <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 9 % </NUMEX>increase is serious in itself , but what is even worse is that excluding food and energy , the producer price index still increased by <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 7 % </NUMEX>, ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Gordon Richards </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">economist </ENAMEX>at the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">National Association of Manufacturers </ENAMEX>. 
1715 But <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Sung Won Sohn </ENAMEX>, chief <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">economist </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Norwest Corp . </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Minneapolis </ENAMEX>, blamed rising energy prices and the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">annual </TIMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">autumn </TIMEX>increase in car prices for most of the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>jump . 
1888 ` I would say this is not bad news ; this is a blip , ' he said . 
1949 ` The core rate is not really out of line . ' 
1994 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">All year </TIMEX>, energy prices have skewed the producer price index , which measures changes in the prices <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">producers </ENAMEX>receive for goods . 
2122 Inflation unquestionably has fallen back from its torrid pace <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last winter </TIMEX>, when a steep run - up in world oil prices sent the index surging at double - digit <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">annual </TIMEX>rates . 
2290 Energy prices then plummeted through <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the summer </TIMEX>, causing the index to decline for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">three consecutive months </TIMEX>. 
2400 Overall , the index has climbed at a <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">5 . 1 % </NUMEX>compound <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">annual </TIMEX>rate since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the start of the year </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Labor Department </ENAMEX>said . 
2518 While far more restrained than the pace <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">at the beginning of the year </TIMEX>, that is still a steeper rise than the <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">4 . 0 % </NUMEX>increase for all of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>. 
2659 Moreover , <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>' s good inflation news may have ended <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>, when energy prices zoomed up <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">6 . 5 % </NUMEX>after plunging <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">7 . 3 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">August </TIMEX>. 
2793 Some <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>expect oil prices to remain relatively stable in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the months ahead </TIMEX>, leaving the future pace of inflation uncertain . 
2924 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Analysts </ENAMEX>had expected that the climb in oil prices <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>would lead to a substantial rise in the producer price index , but the <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 9 % </NUMEX>climb was higher than most anticipated .

9 It was <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday the 13th </TIMEX>, and the stock market plummeted <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">nearly 200 </NUMEX>points . 
83 Just a coincidence ? 
103 Or is <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">triskaidekaphobia </ENAMEX>- - fear of the number <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">13 </NUMEX>- - justified ? 
168 In academia , a so - called <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday the 13th </TIMEX>effect has been set up and shot down by different <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">professors </ENAMEX>. 
273 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Robert Kolb </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Ricardo Rodriguez </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">professors </ENAMEX>of finance at the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">University of Miami </ENAMEX>, found evidence that the market is spooked by <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday the 13th </TIMEX>. 
420 But their study , which spanned the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">1962 - 85 </TIMEX>period , has since been shown to be jinxed by an unlucky choice of data . 
537 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the ' 70s </TIMEX>, the market took falls <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">nine </NUMEX>times in a row on <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday the you - know - what </TIMEX>. 
621 But the date tends to be a plus , not a minus , for stocks , according to <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Yale Hirsch </ENAMEX>, a collector of stock market lore . 
741 Another study found that the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">82 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Fridays the 13th </TIMEX>in the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">1940 - 1987 </TIMEX>period had higher than average returns - - higher even than <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Fridays </TIMEX>in general , which tend to be strong <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">days </TIMEX>for stock prices . 
935 On <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the only other Friday the 13th this year </TIMEX>, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">about four </NUMEX>points . 
1039 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Professor </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Kolb </ENAMEX>says the original study , titled <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">Friday the 13th , Part VII </ENAMEX>, was published tongue - in - cheek . 
1144 In a similar vein , he adds that the anniversary of the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash and <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Saturday </TIMEX>' s full moon could have played a part , too , in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s market activity .

9 The debate over National Service has begun again . 
59 After <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">a decade </TIMEX>in which <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">more than 50 </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:OTHER">localities </ENAMEX>established their own service or conservation <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">corps </ENAMEX>and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">dozens </NUMEX>of school <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">systems </ENAMEX>made community service a prerequisite to high - school graduation , the focus has shifted to <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Washington </ENAMEX>. 
292 At least <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">10 </NUMEX>bills proposing one or another national program were introduced in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this spring </TIMEX>. 
393 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX>, co - sponsored by <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Sam Nunn </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Ga . </ENAMEX>-RRB- and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Rep . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Dave McCurdy </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Okla . </ENAMEX>-RRB- , would have restricted federal college subsidies to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>who had served . 
549 An omnibus bill assembled by <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Edward Kennedy </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Mass . </ENAMEX>-RRB- , and including some diluted <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Nunn </ENAMEX>- <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">McCurdy </ENAMEX>provisions along with proposals by fellow <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Democratic </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sens . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Claiborne Pell </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Barbara Mikulski </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Christopher Dodd </ENAMEX>, has been reported out of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate Labor Committee </ENAMEX>. 
818 It might well win <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>passage . 
852 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">President </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX>has outlined his own Youth Entering Service -LRB- YES -RRB- plan , though its details remain to be specified . 
968 What is one to think of all this ? 
1002 Doctrine and special interests govern some responses . 
1056 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">People </ENAMEX>eager to have youth ` pay their dues to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">society </ENAMEX>' favor service proposals - - preferably mandatory ones . 
1165 So do those who seek a ` re - energized concept of citizenship , ' a concept imposing stern obligations as well as conferring rights . 
1294 Then there are instinctive <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">opponents </ENAMEX>. 
1332 To <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">libertarians </ENAMEX>, mandatory service is an abomination and voluntary systems are illegitimate uses of tax money . 
1443 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Devotees </ENAMEX>of the market question the value of the work national service would perform : 
1529 If the market wo n't pay for it , they argue , it ca n't be worth its cost . 
1601 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Elements </ENAMEX>of the left are also reflexively opposed ; they see service as a cover for the draft , or fear the regimentation of youth , or want to see rights enlarged , not obligations . 
1782 But what about those of us whose views are not predetermined by formula or ideology ? 
1867 How should we think about national service ? 
1911 Let ' s begin by recognizing a main source of confusion - - ` national service ' has no agreed meaning . 
2010 Would service be voluntary or compulsory ? 
2052 Short or long ? 
2067 Part - time or full - time ? 
2091 Paid or unpaid ? 
2107 Would <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">participants </ENAMEX>live at <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">home </ENAMEX>and work nearby or live in <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">barracks </ENAMEX>and work on public lands ? 
2201 What kinds of work would they do ? 
2237 What does ` national ' mean ? 
2264 Would the program be run by the federal <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>, by local <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">governments </ENAMEX>, or by private voluntary <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">organizations </ENAMEX>? 
2377 And who would serve ? 
2398 Only <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">males </ENAMEX>, as with the draft , or both <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">sexes </ENAMEX>? 
2444 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Youth </ENAMEX>only or all ages ? 
2468 Middle - class <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>, or poor <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>, or a genuine cross - section ? 
2533 Many or few ? 
2548 Those are not trivial questions , and the label ` national service ' answers none of them . 
2636 Then how should we think about national service ? 
2685 As a starting point , here are <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">five </NUMEX>propositions : <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">1 </NUMEX>. Consider the ingredients , not the name . 
2779 Ignore ` national service ' in the abstract ; consider specific proposals . 
2851 They will differ in crucial ways . 
2887 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">2 </NUMEX>. ` Service ' should be service . 
2919 As commonly understood , service implies sacrifice . 
2970 It involves accepting risk , or giving up income , or deferring a career . 
3042 It follows that proposals like <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Nunn </ENAMEX>- <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">McCurdy </ENAMEX>, whose benefits to enrollees are worth <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">some $ 17 , 500 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">a year </TIMEX>, do not qualify . 
3162 There is a rationale for such bills : Federal subsidies to college <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>amount to ` a <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">GI Bill </ENAMEX>without the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">GI </ENAMEX>' ; arguably those benefits should be earned , not given . 
3328 But the earnings exceed by <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">20 % </NUMEX>the average income of young high - school <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">graduates </ENAMEX>with full - time jobs . 
3430 Why call that service ? 
3455 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">3 </NUMEX>. Encouragement is fine ; compulsion is not . 
3500 Compelled service is unconstitutional . 
3539 It is also unwise and unenforceable . 
3576 -LRB- Who will throw <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">several hundred thousand </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">refusers </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">jail </ENAMEX>each year ? -RRB- 
3646 But through tax policy and in other ways the federal government encourages many kinds of behavior . 
3745 It should also encourage service - - preferably by all classes and all ages . 
3821 Its encouragement should strengthen and not undercut the strong tradition of volunteering in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>, should build on the service programs already in existence , and should honor local convictions about which tasks most need doing . 
4055 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">4 </NUMEX>. Good programs are not cheap . 
4087 Enthusiasts assume that national service would get important work done cheaply : forest fires fought , housing rehabilitated , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">students </ENAMEX>tutored , day - care <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">centers </ENAMEX>staffed . 
4255 There is important work to be done , and existing service and conservation <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">corps </ENAMEX>have shown that even <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">youths </ENAMEX>who start with few skills can do much of it well - - but not cheaply . 
4434 Good service programs require recruitment , screening , training and supervision - - all of high quality . 
4537 They involve stipends to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">participants </ENAMEX>. 
4576 Full - time residential programs also require housing and full - time supervision ; they are particularly expensive - - more per <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">participant </ENAMEX>than <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">a year </TIMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">Stanford </ENAMEX>or <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">Yale </ENAMEX>. 
4744 Non - residential programs are cheaper , but good ones still come to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">some $ 10 , 000 </NUMEX>a year . 
4831 Are they worth that ? 
4852 Evaluations suggest that good ones are - - especially so if the effects on <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">participants </ENAMEX>are counted . 
4952 But the calculations are challengeable . 
4994 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">5 </NUMEX>. Underclass <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">youth </ENAMEX>are a special concern . 
5037 Are such expenditures worthwhile , then ? 
5077 Yes , if targeted . 
5095 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">People </ENAMEX>of all ages and all classes should be encouraged to serve , but there are many ways for middle - class <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">kids </ENAMEX>, and their <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">elders </ENAMEX>, to serve at little public cost . 
5258 They can volunteer at any of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">thousands </NUMEX>of non - profit <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">institutions </ENAMEX>, or participate in service programs required by high <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">schools </ENAMEX>or encouraged by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">colleges </ENAMEX>or <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">employers </ENAMEX>. 
5427 Underclass <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">youth </ENAMEX>do n't have those opportunities . 
5476 They are not enrolled in high <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">school </ENAMEX>or <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:EDUCATIONAL">college </ENAMEX>. 
5525 They are unlikely to be employed . 
5559 And they have grown up in unprecedentedly grim circumstances , among family structures breaking down , surrounded by self - destructive behaviors and bleak prospects . 
5722 But many of them can be quite profoundly reoriented by productive and disciplined service . 
5815 Some wo n't accept the discipline ; others drop out for other reasons . 
5884 But some whom nothing else is reaching are transformed . 
5940 Learning skills , producing something cooperatively , feeling useful , they are no longer dependent - - others now depend on them . 
6067 Even if it is cheaper to build <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:ATTRACTION">playgrounds </ENAMEX>or paint <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">apartments </ENAMEX>or plant dune - <ENAMEX TYPE="PLANT">grass </ENAMEX>with paid <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">professionals </ENAMEX>, the effects on the young <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>providing those services alter the calculation . 
6257 Strictly speaking , these <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">youth </ENAMEX>are not performing service . 
6316 They are giving up no income , deferring no careers , incurring no risk . 
6387 But they believe themselves to be serving , and they begin to respect themselves -LRB- and others -RRB- , to take control of their lives , to think of the future . 
6537 That is a service to the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">nation </ENAMEX>. 
6570 It is what federal support should try hardest to achieve . 
6630 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Szanton </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Carter </ENAMEX>administration budget <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">official </ENAMEX>, heads his own <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Washington </ENAMEX>- based strategic planning <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX>. 
6740 He is a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">co - author </ENAMEX>of ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:BOOK">National Service : What Would It Mean </ENAMEX>? ' 
6801 -LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Lexington Books </ENAMEX>, <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1986 </TIMEX>-RRB- .  

9 The carnage among takeover stocks <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>does n't mean the end of mega - mergers but simply marks the start of a less ambitious game , Wall Street ' s big - time deal <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">makers </ENAMEX>say . 
182 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Suitors </ENAMEX>from now on are more likely to be expansion - minded <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>, rather than <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">raiders </ENAMEX>or debt - happy <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">financiers </ENAMEX>. 
298 And they will be launching lower - priced and perhaps fewer deals , now that it ' s tougher to finance them . 
404 This is an ominous sign for a stock market that lately has been fueled by takeover speculation and bidding wars for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>that put themselves up for sale . 
563 Whenever <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1980s </TIMEX>merger boom seems to be stalling , shock waves ripple through the stock market . 
663 ` The market is overvalued , not cheap , ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Alan Gaines </ENAMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>money - management <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firm </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Gaines Berland </ENAMEX>. 
773 He recently began increasing his cash position to <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">45 % </NUMEX>of his portfolio . 
845 ` I look at where deals can get done , ' he says , ` and they ' re not getting done ' at current prices . 
944 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Lenders </ENAMEX>are growing increasingly nervous about debt - financed takeovers , investment <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">bankers </ENAMEX>say . 
1040 ` You had a <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">week </TIMEX>of a deteriorating junk - bond market that ran smack into the news on <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>about what appeared to be happening to the bank debt market , ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Steven Rattner </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">partner </ENAMEX>and merger <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">specialist </ENAMEX>with <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Lazard Freres &amp; Co .  
1273 Trading dried up <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>in the market for high - yield junk bonds , often used to finance takeovers . 
1371 It was the latest in a series of setbacks for the junk bond market , where prices began weakening <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>after <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Campeau </ENAMEX>hit a cash crunch . 
1514 And <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">banks </ENAMEX>appear to be taking an increasingly skeptical view of requests for high - risk takeover loans . 
1617 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">group </ENAMEX>trying to buy <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">UAL </ENAMEX>announced <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>that it could n't arrange the <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 7 . 2 billion </NUMEX>in bank loans it needs to buy the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">parent </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">United Airlines </ENAMEX>for <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 300 </NUMEX>a share . 
1784 Takeover - stock <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">traders </ENAMEX>today will be scrambling to learn of any <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">UAL </ENAMEX>developments , and other takeover stocks are likely to trade in sympathy . 
1925 Investment <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">bankers </ENAMEX>representing the buy - out <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">group </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">UAL </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">board </ENAMEX>spent <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">a frantic weekend </TIMEX>trying to hammer out new terms that would be more acceptable to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">banks </ENAMEX>. 
2092 After <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">UAL </ENAMEX>, the stock viewed as most vulnerable is <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">American Airlines </ENAMEX>' <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">parent </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">AMR </ENAMEX>, the target of a <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 120 </NUMEX>- a - share takeover proposal from <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>real estate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">developer </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Donald Trump </ENAMEX>. 
2270 Trading in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">AMR </ENAMEX>shares was suspended shortly after <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">3 p . m . EDT </TIMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>and did n't resume . 
2357 Before the halt , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">AMR </ENAMEX>last traded at <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">98 5 \/ 8 </NUMEX>.

2531 Similarly , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Delta Air Lines </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">USAir Group </ENAMEX>dropped <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">10 . 1 % and 8 . 5 % </NUMEX>, respectively , on <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>and could weaken further . 
2650 Over <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the weeked </TIMEX>, however , <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>developments in other deals indicated that commerical <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">banks </ENAMEX>and Wall Street <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>still are willing to commit <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">billions of dollars </NUMEX>to finance takeover bids launched by major <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>. 
2866 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Vitro S . 9 When <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">William Brennan </ENAMEX>marks the start of his <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">34th </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year </TIMEX>on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Supreme Court </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>, the occasion will differ sharply from previous anniversaries of his tenure . 
177 For the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>time , the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">83 - year - old </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">justice </ENAMEX>finds his influence almost exclusively in dissent , rather than as a force in the high <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">majority </ENAMEX>. 
325 This role reversal holds true , as well , for his <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">three </NUMEX>liberal and moderate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">allies </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justices </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Thurgood Marshall </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Harry Blackmun </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John Stevens </ENAMEX>. 
471 But are these <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">players </ENAMEX>, <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">three </NUMEX>of them in their <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">80s </TIMEX>, ready to assume a different role after <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">88 years </TIMEX>, collectively , of service on the high <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>? 
622 Every indication is that the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX>are prepared to accept this new role , and the frustrations that go with it , but in different ways . 
755 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justices </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brennan </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Stevens </ENAMEX>appear philosophical about it ; <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justices </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Marshall </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Blackmun </ENAMEX>appear fighting mad . 
869 The <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">justices </ENAMEX>are no <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">newcomers </ENAMEX>to dissent , often joining forces in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the past decade </TIMEX>to criticize the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>' s conservative drift . 
1001 But always , in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">years past </TIMEX>, they have bucked the trend and have been able to pick up a <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">fifth </NUMEX>vote to eke out a number of major victories in civil rights and liberties cases . 
1174 Now , however , as the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>' s new <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">five </NUMEX>- member conservative <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">majority </ENAMEX>continues to solidify , victories for the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">liberals </ENAMEX>are rare . 
1303 The change is most dramatic for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brennan </ENAMEX>, the last <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">survivor </ENAMEX>of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the mid - 1960s </TIMEX>liberal <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">majority </ENAMEX>under <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Chief Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Earl Warren </ENAMEX>. 
1437 In the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">seven </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Supreme Court </ENAMEX>terms <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">from the fall of 1962 through the spring of 1967 </TIMEX>, the height of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Warren </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">Court </ENAMEX>' s power , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brennan </ENAMEX>cast <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">only 25 </NUMEX>dissenting votes in <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">555 </NUMEX>cases decided by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>. 
1641 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Last term </TIMEX>alone he cast <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">52 </NUMEX>dissenting votes in <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">133 </NUMEX>decisions , with the contentious flag - burning ruling as his only big victory . 
1771 But <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brennan </ENAMEX>foresaw his new role , strongly defending the importance of dissents in a <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1985 </TIMEX>speech . 
1877 ` Each time the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>revisits an issue , the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">justices </ENAMEX>will be forced by a dissent to reconsider the fundamental questions and to rethink the result , ' he said . 
2035 Moreover , in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent months </TIMEX>he has said that when he was on the winning <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">side </ENAMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1960s </TIMEX>, he knew that the tables might turn in the future . 
2175 He has said that he now knows how <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John Harlan </ENAMEX>felt , a reference to the late conservative <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">justice </ENAMEX>who was the most frequent dissenter from the <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Warren </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">Court </ENAMEX>' s opinions . 
2352 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Associates </ENAMEX>of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">81 - year - old </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Marshall </ENAMEX>say he was ` depressed ' about the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>' s direction <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last spring </TIMEX>, but is feisty about his role and determined to speak out against the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>' s cutbacks in civil rights . 
2562 ` We could sweep it under the rug and hide it , but I ' m not going to do it , ' he said in a speech <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>. 
2671 He , like <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brennan </ENAMEX>, considers dissents highly important for the future , a point that has n't escaped legal <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">scholars </ENAMEX>. 
2793 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">Harvard Law School </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Professor </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Laurence Tribe </ENAMEX>says there is a ` generation - skipping ' flavor to current dissents . 
2903 The <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">dissenters </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Warren </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">Court </ENAMEX>, he says , appeared to be writing for the short - term , suggesting that the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>' s direction might change soon . 
3048 ` <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Brennan </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Marshall </ENAMEX>are speaking in their dissents to a more distant future , ' he says . 
3139 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Blackmun </ENAMEX>, who will turn <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">81 </TIMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next month </TIMEX>, also seems feisty about his new role . 
3224 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Associates </ENAMEX>say he takes some defeats more personally than his <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">colleagues </ENAMEX>, especially attempts to curtail the right to abortion <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>recognized in his <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1973 </TIMEX>opinion , <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Roe </ENAMEX>vs . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Wade </ENAMEX>.

3922 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Justice </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Stevens </ENAMEX>, <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">69 </TIMEX>, is probably the most philosophical of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">dissenters </ENAMEX>about his role , in part because he may be the least <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">liberal </ENAMEX>of the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">four </NUMEX>, but also because he enjoys the intellectual challenge of arguing with the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">majority </ENAMEX>more than the others .

E . 9 The <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>, which is finalizing its steel - import quotas , is allocating a larger share of its steel market to developing and newly industrialized <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">countries </ENAMEX>which have relatively unsubsidized steel industries . 
217 Meanwhile , the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>has negotiated a significant cut in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Japan </ENAMEX>' s steel quota , and made only a minor increase to the steel allotment for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">European Community </ENAMEX>. 
378 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Brazil </ENAMEX>, similar to <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Mexico </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">South Korea </ENAMEX>, is expected to negotiate a somewhat bigger share of the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>market than it had under the previous <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">five - year </TIMEX>steel quotas , which expired <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Sept . 30 </TIMEX>. 
568 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Brazil </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Venezuela </ENAMEX>are the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">only two </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">countries </ENAMEX>that have n't completed steel talks with the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the year ending Oct . 1 , 1990 </TIMEX>. 
701 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent years </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">steelmakers </ENAMEX>have supplied <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 80 % </NUMEX>of the <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:WEIGHT">100 million tons </NUMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">steel </ENAMEX>used <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">annually </TIMEX>by the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">nation </ENAMEX>. 
821 Of the remaining <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">20 % </NUMEX>needed , the steel - quota negotiations allocate <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 15 % </NUMEX>to foreign <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">suppliers </ENAMEX>, with the difference supplied mainly by <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Canada </ENAMEX>- - which is n't included in the quota program . 
1012 Other <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">countries </ENAMEX>that do n't have formal steel quotas with the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . 1257 The <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">administration </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">earlier this year </TIMEX>said it would extend steel quotas , known as voluntary restraint agreements , until <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">March 31 , 1992 </TIMEX>. 
1397 It also said it would use <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">that two - and - a - half year </TIMEX>period to work toward an international consensus on freeing up the international steel trade , which has been notoriously managed , subsidized and protected by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">governments </ENAMEX>. 
1619 The <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>termed its plan , a ` trade liberalization program , ' despite the fact that it is merely an extension . 
1730 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Mexico </ENAMEX>, which was <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">countries </ENAMEX>to conclude its steel talks with the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>steel market from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 48 % </NUMEX>under the previous quotas . 
1918 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">South Korea </ENAMEX>, which had <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">1 . 9 % </NUMEX>under the previous quotas , is set to get a small increase to <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 1 . 95 % </NUMEX>. 
2020 That increase rises to slightly more than <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">2 % </NUMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>market if a joint <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">Korean </ENAMEX>- <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>steel project is included .

334 The toy <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>were pushed across the border by rising labor and land costs in the <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">British </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">colony </ENAMEX>. 
433 But in the wake of the shootings in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Beijing </ENAMEX>on <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">June 4 </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Hong Kong </ENAMEX>toy industry is worrying about its strong dependence on <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">China </ENAMEX>. 
565 Although the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">manufacturers </ENAMEX>stress that production has n't been affected by <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">China </ENAMEX>' s political turmoil , they are looking for additional sites . 
705 The toy <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">makers </ENAMEX>, and their foreign <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">buyers </ENAMEX>, cite uncertainty about <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">China </ENAMEX>' s economic and political policies .

S . </ENAMEX>is transported on <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Interprovincial </ENAMEX>' s system , whose main line runs from <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Edmonton </ENAMEX>to major <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">Canadian </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:CITY">cities </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Great Lakes </ENAMEX>region , including <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Chicago </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Buffalo </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Toronto </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Montreal </ENAMEX>. 
2171 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Canada </ENAMEX>' s current <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">oil </ENAMEX>exports to the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>total <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">about 600 , 000 barrels </NUMEX>a day , or <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 9 . 1 % </NUMEX>of net <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">crude </ENAMEX>imports , said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John Lichtblau </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>- based <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Petroleum Industry Research Foundation </ENAMEX>. 
2381 That ranks <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Canada </ENAMEX>as the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">fourth </NUMEX>- largest source of imported <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">crude </ENAMEX>, behind <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Saudi Arabia </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Nigeria </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Mexico </ENAMEX>. 
2490 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Lichtblau </ENAMEX>said <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Canada </ENAMEX>' s declining crude output , combined with the fast - shrinking output of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">crude </ENAMEX>, will help intensify <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>reliance on <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">oil </ENAMEX>from overseas , particularly the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Middle East </ENAMEX>. 
2683 ` It ' s very much a growing concern . 
2718 But when something is inevitable , you learn to live with it , ' he said . 
2791 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Lichtblau </ENAMEX>stressed that the delay of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Interprovincial </ENAMEX>' s proposed expansion wo n't by itself increase <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>dependence on offshore <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">crude </ENAMEX>, however , since <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">Canadian </ENAMEX>imports are limited in any case by <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Canada </ENAMEX>' s falling output . 
3015 Under terms of its proposed <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>- step expansion , which would have required regulatory approval , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Interprovincial </ENAMEX>intended to add <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">200 , 000 barrels </NUMEX>a day of additional capacity to its system , beginning with a modest expansion by <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1991 </TIMEX>. 
3245 The system currently has a capacity of <NUMEX TYPE="QUANTITY:3D">1 . 55 million barrels </NUMEX>a day .

2479 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">4 </NUMEX>. 2884 The problem , which the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Journal </ENAMEX>so rightly pointed out in a number of articles , is not the likes of Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Lantos </ENAMEX>, who after all is really a bit <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">player </ENAMEX>on the stage , but the attempt by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX>to enhance itself into a quasi - parliamentary \/ judicial <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">body </ENAMEX>.
