3749 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Raymond Weber  
3765 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Parsippany </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">N . J .  
3784 I disagree with the statement by Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Lantos </ENAMEX>that one should not draw an adverse inference against former <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">HUD </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">officials </ENAMEX>who assert their <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth Amendment </ENAMEX>privilege against self - incrimination in congressional hearings . 
4002 The <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth Amendment </ENAMEX>states in relevant part that no <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">person </ENAMEX>` shall be compelled , in any criminal case , to be a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">witness </ENAMEX>against himself . ' 
4138 This privilege against self - incrimination precludes the drawing of an adverse inference against a criminal <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>who chooses not to testify . 
4283 Thus , in a criminal case , a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">prosecutor </ENAMEX>can not comment on a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>' s failure to testify nor can the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>be compelled to take the stand as a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">witness </ENAMEX>, thus forcing him to ` take the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth </ENAMEX>. ' 
4478 The privilege , however , has been limited in accordance with its plain language to protect the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>in criminal matters only . 
4610 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Supreme Court </ENAMEX>and some <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>have specifically recognized that ` the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth Amendment </ENAMEX>does not preclude the inference where the privilege is claimed by a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">party </ENAMEX>to a civil cause . ' 
4794 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Baxter </ENAMEX>v . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Palmingiano </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">425 U . S . 308 </ENAMEX>-LRB- <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1976 </TIMEX>-RRB- . 
4838 Thus , in a civil case , a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>may be called as a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">witness </ENAMEX>, he may be forced to testify or take the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth </ENAMEX>, and his taking of the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth </ENAMEX>may permit the drawing of an adverse inference against him in the civil matter . 
5056 He may take the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth </ENAMEX>in a civil matter only if he has a good faith and justifiable belief that his testimony may subject him to criminal prosecution . 
5207 Allowing the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>to take the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth </ENAMEX>in a civil matter is not based on a constitutional right to refuse to testify where one ' s testimony harms him in the civil matter , but because the testimony in the civil matter could be unconstitutionally used against him in a subsequent criminal prosecution . 
5508 Absent the risk of such prosecution , a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">court </ENAMEX>may order the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">defendant </ENAMEX>to testify . 
5591 Thus , when Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>asserted the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth </ENAMEX>in a noncriminal proceeding , particularly after presumably receiving extensive advice from legal <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">counsel </ENAMEX>, <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>must conclude that he held a good - faith , justifiable belief that his testimony could be used against him in a subsequent criminal prosecution . 
5885 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">subcommittee </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">American </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">public </ENAMEX>have every right to draw the adverse inference and to concur with Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>' s own belief that his testimony could help convict him of a crime . 
6080 Drawing the adverse inference in a noncriminal congressional hearing does not offend the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Fifth Amendment </ENAMEX>shield against self - incrimination . 
6222 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Clark S . Spalsbury Jr .  
6247 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Estes Park </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Colo .

881 To make its point , it is challenging the <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">Italian </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>to explain reports that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Olivetti </ENAMEX>may have supplied the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Soviet Union </ENAMEX>with sophisticated computer - driven devices that could be used to build parts for combat <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT_DESC:VEHICLE">aircraft </ENAMEX>.

9 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">190 </NUMEX>- point plunge in stocks does not come atop the climate of anxiety that dominated financial markets just prior to their <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 October </TIMEX>crash , and mechanisms have been put in place to keep markets more orderly .

648 This observation leads us to another piece of news moving on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Dow Jones </ENAMEX>ticker shortly before the downturn : the success of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Democrats </ENAMEX>in stalling the capital gains tax cut . 
832 The real value of all shares , after all , is directly impacted by the tax on any profits -LRB- all the more so given the limits on deductions for losses that show gains are not ` ordinary income ' -RRB- . 
1023 And market expectations clearly have been raised by the capital gains victory in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last month </TIMEX>. 
1126 <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">An hour </TIMEX>before <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s plunge , that provision was stripped from the tax bill , leaving it with <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 5 . 4 billion </NUMEX>in tax increases without a capital gains cut . 
1282 There is a great deal to be said , to be sure , for stripping the garbage out of the reconciliation bill . 
1386 It would be a good thing if <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX>started to decide issues <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>- by - <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>on their individual merits without trickery . 
1504 For <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>thing , no one doubts that the capital gains cut would pass on an up - or - down vote .

1710 Especially so since <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">President </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX>has been weakened by the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Panama </ENAMEX>fiasco .

1908 As the best opportunities for corporate restructurings are exhausted of course , at some point the market will start to reject them . 
2040 But the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">airlines </ENAMEX>are scarcely a clear case , given anti - takeover mischief by <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Secretary </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Transportation </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Skinner </ENAMEX>, who professes to believe safety will be compromised if <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">KLM </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">British Airways </ENAMEX>own interests in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>that fly <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT_DESC:VEHICLE">airplanes </ENAMEX>.

2760 So the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">UAL </ENAMEX>deal has problems , and the market loses <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">190 </NUMEX>points . 
2823 Congratulations , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Secretary </ENAMEX>and Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Congressman </ENAMEX>. 
2877 In the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash , remember , the market was shaken by a <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Danny Rostenkowski </ENAMEX>proposal to tax takeovers out of existance . 
2996 Even more important , in our view , was the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>' s threat to thrash the dollar .

1192 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Elaine Garzarelli </ENAMEX>. 
1211 A quantitative <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>with <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc . </ENAMEX>, Ms . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Garzarelli </ENAMEX>had warned <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">clients </ENAMEX>to take their money out of the market before the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash . 
1365 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s big drop , she says , ` was not a crash . 
1412 This was an <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October </TIMEX>massacre ' like those that occurred in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1978 </TIMEX>and <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1979 </TIMEX>. 
1485 Now , as in those <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">two years </TIMEX>, her stock market indicators are positive . 
1555 So she thinks the damage will be short - lived and contained . 
1617 ` Those corrections lasted <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">one to four weeks </TIMEX>and took the market <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">10 % - 12 % </NUMEX>down , ' she says . 
1706 ` This is exactly the same thing , as far as I ' m concerned . ' 
1765 Thus , she says , if the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped below <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">2450 </NUMEX>, ` It would just be a fluke . 
1864 My advice is to buy . ' 
1888 As she calculates it , the average stock now sells for <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">about 12 . 5 </NUMEX>times <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>' earnings . 
1980 She says that ratio could climb to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">14 . 5 </NUMEX>, given current interest rates , and still be within the range of ` fair value . ' 
2100 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Ned Davis </ENAMEX>. 
2111 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s fall marks the start of a bear market , says Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Davis </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Ned Davis Research Inc .  
2212 But Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Davis </ENAMEX>, whose views are widely respected by money <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">managers </ENAMEX>, says he expects no <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>- style crash . 
2318 ` There was a unique combination in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, ' he says . 
2369 ` Margin debt was at a record high . 
2404 There was tremendous public enthusiasm for stock mutual funds . 
2467 The main thing was portfolio insurance , ' a mechanical trading system intended to protect an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investor </ENAMEX>against losses . 
2584 ` A <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">hundred billion dollars </NUMEX>in stock was subject ' to it . 
2640 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, such selling contributed to a snowball effect . 
2698 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Today </TIMEX>could even be <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">an up day </TIMEX>, Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Davis </ENAMEX>says , if major brokerage <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">firms </ENAMEX>agree to refrain from program trading . 
2809 Over <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the next several months </TIMEX>, though , he says things look bad . 
2874 ` I think the market will be heading down into <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">November </TIMEX>, ' he says . 
2940 ` We will probably have a <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - end </TIMEX>rally , and then go down again . 
3005 Sort of a <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>- step bear market . ' 
3038 He expects the downturn to carry the Dow Jones Industrial Average down to around <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">2000 </NUMEX>sometime <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next year </TIMEX>. 
3144 ` That would be a normal bear market , ' he says . 
3191 ` I guess that ' s my forecast . ' 
3223 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Leon G . Cooperman </ENAMEX>. 
3242 ` I do n't think the market is going through another <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October ' 87 </TIMEX>. 
3306 I do n't think that ' s the case at all , ' says Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Cooperman </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">partner </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Goldman , Sachs &amp; Co . </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chairman </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Goldman Sachs Asset Management </ENAMEX>. 
3449 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Cooperman </ENAMEX>sees this as a good time to pick up bargains , but he does n't think there ' s any need to rush . 
3556 ` I expect the market to open weaker <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Monday </TIMEX>, but then it should find some stability . ' 
3643 He ticks off several major differences between <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">now </TIMEX>and <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">two years ago </TIMEX>. 
3713 Unlike <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, interest rates have been falling <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. 
3770 Unlike <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, the dollar has been strong . 
3811 And unlike <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>, the economy does n't appear to be in any danger of overheating . 
3893 But the economy ' s slower growth <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>also means the outlook for corporate profits ` is n't good , ' he says . 
4003 ` So it ' s a very mixed bag . ' 
4033 Thus , he concludes , ` This is not a good environment to be fully invested ' in stocks . 
4118 ` If I had come into <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>on margin or with very little cash in the portfolios , I would not do any buying . 
4226 But we came into <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>with a conservative portfolio , so I would look to do some modest buying ' on behalf of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">clients </ENAMEX>. 
4345 ` We ' re going to look for some of the better - known <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>that got clocked ' <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>. 
4433 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John Kenneth Galbraith </ENAMEX>. 
4457 ` This is the latest manifestation of the capacity of the financial community for recurrent <ENAMEX TYPE="DISEASE">insanity </ENAMEX>, ' says Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Galbraith </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">economist </ENAMEX>. 
4595 ` I see this as a reaction to the whole junk bond explosion , ' he says . 
4665 ` The explosion of junk bonds and takeovers has lodged a lot of insecure securities in the hands of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>and loaded the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">corporations </ENAMEX>that are the objects of takeovers or feared takeovers with huge amounts of debt rather than equity . 
4902 This has both made <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>uneasy and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">corporations </ENAMEX>more vulnerable . ' 
4979 Nevertheless , he says a depression does n't appear likely . 
5037 ` There is more resiliency in the economy at large than we commonly suppose , ' he says . 
5123 ` It takes more error now to have a major depression than back in the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Thirties </TIMEX>- - much as the financial <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">community </ENAMEX>and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">government </ENAMEX>may try . ' 
5267 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Mario Gabelli </ENAMEX>. 
5282 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>money <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">manager </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Mario Gabelli </ENAMEX>, an <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">expert </ENAMEX>at spotting takeover <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">candidates </ENAMEX>, says that takeovers are n't totally gone . 
5406 ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Companies </ENAMEX>are still going to buy <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>around the world , ' he says . 
5478 Examples are ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Ford </ENAMEX>looking at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Jaguar </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">BellSouth </ENAMEX>looking at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">LIN Broadcasting </ENAMEX>. ' 
5556 These sorts of takeovers do n't require junk bonds or big bank loans to finance them , so Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Gabelli </ENAMEX>figures they will continue . 
5686 ` The market was up <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">35 % </NUMEX>since -LCB- <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">President </ENAMEX>-RCB- <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX>took office , ' Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Gabelli </ENAMEX>says , so a correction was to be expected . 
5800 He thinks another crash is ` unlikely , ' and says he was ` nibbling at ' selected stocks during <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s plunge . 
5911 ` Stocks that were thrown out just on an emotional basis are a great opportunity -LCB- <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this -RCB- week </TIMEX>for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">guys </ENAMEX>like me , ' he says . 
6033 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Jim Rogers </ENAMEX>. 
6045 ` It seems to me that this is the pin that has finally pricked the balloon , ' says Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Rogers </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">professor </ENAMEX>of finance at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:EDUCATIONAL">Columbia University </ENAMEX>and former <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">co - manager </ENAMEX>of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of the most successful hedge funds in history , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:OTHER">Quantum Fund </ENAMEX>. 
6276 He sees ` economic problems , financial problems ' ahead for the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>, with a fairly strong possibility of a recession . 
6393 ` <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>you could n't sell dollars , ' he says . 
6438 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Dealers </ENAMEX>` would give you a quote , but then refuse to make the trade . ' 
6507 If the dollar stays weak , he says , that will add to inflationary pressures in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>and make it hard for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Reserve Board </ENAMEX>to ease interest rates very much . 
6677 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Rogers </ENAMEX>wo n't decide what to do <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>until he sees how the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">London </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Tokyo </ENAMEX>markets go . 
6769 He recommends that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">investors </ENAMEX>sell takeover - related stocks , but hang on to some other stocks - - especially utilities , which often do well during periods of economic weakness . 
6945 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Frank Curzio </ENAMEX>. 
6959 Many <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>now claim to have predicted the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>crash . 
7015 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:OTHER">Queens </ENAMEX>newsletter <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">writer </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Francis X . Curzio </ENAMEX>actually did it : He stated in writing in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September 1987 </TIMEX>that the Dow Jones Industrial Average was likely to decline <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">about 500 </NUMEX>points <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the following month </TIMEX>. 
7214 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Curzio </ENAMEX>says what happens now will depend a good deal on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Reserve Board </ENAMEX>. 
7301 If it promptly cuts the discount rate it charges on loans to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">banks </ENAMEX>, he says , ` That could quiet things down . '

7453 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Frank W . Terrizzi </ENAMEX>.

7685 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Renaissance </ENAMEX>, which manages <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 1 . 8 billion </NUMEX>, drew stiff criticism from many <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">clients </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">earlier this year </TIMEX>because it pulled entirely out of stocks at <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the beginning of the year </TIMEX>and thus missed a strong rally .

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon Brothers International Ltd . </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:NATIONALITY">British </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">subsidiary </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon Inc . </ENAMEX>, announced it will issue warrants on shares of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd .  
166 The move closely follows a similar offer by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon </ENAMEX>of warrants for shares of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Hongkong &amp; Shanghai Banking Corp .  
280 Under the latest offer , <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">HK $ 62 . 5 million </NUMEX>-LRB- <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">US $ 8 million </NUMEX>-RRB- of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">three - year </TIMEX>warrants will be issued in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">London </ENAMEX>, each giving <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">buyers </ENAMEX>the right to buy <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Hong Kong Telecommunications </ENAMEX>share at a price to be determined <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>. 
497 The <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">50 million </NUMEX>warrants will be priced at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">HK $ 1 . 25 </NUMEX>each and are expected to carry a premium to the share price of <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 26 % </NUMEX>. 
621 In trading on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Stock Exchange </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Hong Kong </ENAMEX>, the shares closed <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Wednesday </TIMEX>at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">HK $ 4 . 80 </NUMEX>each . 
713 At this price , the shares would have to rise above <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">HK $ 6 . 05 </NUMEX>for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">subscribers </ENAMEX>to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon </ENAMEX>' s issue to profitably convert their warrants . 
847 While <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Hong Kong </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>have in the past issued warrants on their own shares , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon </ENAMEX>' s warrants are the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>here to be issued by a <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">third </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">party </ENAMEX>. 
996 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon </ENAMEX>will ` cover ' the warrants by buying sufficient shares , or options to purchase shares , to cover its entire position . 
1122 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Bankers </ENAMEX>said warrants for <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Hong Kong </ENAMEX>stocks are attractive because they give foreign <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>, wary of volatility in the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">colony </ENAMEX>' s stock market , an opportunity to buy shares without taking too great a risk . 
1330 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Hong Kong Telecommunications </ENAMEX>warrants should be attractive to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">buyers </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:CONTINENT">Europe </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">bankers </ENAMEX>added , because the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">group </ENAMEX>is one of a handful of blue - chip stocks on the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Hong Kong </ENAMEX>market that has international appeal .

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Kaufman &amp; Broad Home Corp . </ENAMEX>said it formed a <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 53 . 4 million </NUMEX>limited partnership <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">subsidiary </ENAMEX>to buy land in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">California </ENAMEX>suitable for residential development .

579 The land to be purchased by the joint <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">venture </ENAMEX>has n't yet received zoning and other approvals required for development , and part of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Kaufman &amp; Broad </ENAMEX>' s job will be to obtain such approvals . 
768 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">partnership </ENAMEX>runs the risk that it may not get the approvals for development , but in return , it can buy land at wholesale rather than retail prices , which can result in sizable savings , said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bruce Karatz </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">president </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chief executive officer </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Kaufman &amp; Broad </ENAMEX>. 
1036 ` There are really very few <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>that have adequate capital to buy properties in a raw state for cash . 
1143 Typically , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">developers </ENAMEX>option property , and then once they get the administrative approvals , they buy it , ' said Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Karatz </ENAMEX>, adding that he believes the joint <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">venture </ENAMEX>is the <NUMEX TYPE="ORDINAL">first </NUMEX>of its kind . 
1334 ` We usually operate in that conservative manner . ' 
1386 By setting up the joint <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">venture </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Kaufman &amp; Broad </ENAMEX>can take the more aggressive approach of buying raw land , while avoiding the negative impacts to its own balance sheet , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Karatz </ENAMEX>said . 
1572 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>is putting up <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">only 10 % </NUMEX>of the capital , although it is responsible for providing management , planning and processing services to the joint <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">venture </ENAMEX>. 
1733 ` This is <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of the best ways to assure a <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:OTHER">pipeline </ENAMEX>of land to fuel our growth at a minimum risk to our <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>, ' Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Karatz </ENAMEX>said .

9 The market for <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 200 billion </NUMEX>of high - risk junk bonds , battered by a succession of defaults and huge price declines <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>, practically vanished <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>.

Sass </ENAMEX>, who manages <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">nearly $ 4 billion </NUMEX>and who recently decided to buy distressed securities for a new fund .

4389 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Robert Dow </ENAMEX>, a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">partner </ENAMEX>and portfolio <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">manager </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Lord , Abbett &amp; Co . </ENAMEX>, which manages <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 4 billion </NUMEX>of high - yield bonds , says he does n't ` think there is any fundamental economic rationale -LCB- for the junk bond rout -RCB- .

4803 I do n't believe that ' s the case , but I believe that <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>are running scared . 
4882 There is a flight to quality , and the quality is not in equities and not in junk - - it ' s in Treasurys . '

5407 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">First Boston </ENAMEX>estimates that in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">November </TIMEX>and <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">December </TIMEX>alone , junk bond <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>will receive <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 4 . 8 billion </NUMEX>of coupon interest payments .

5677 ` I do n't know how <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>can say the junk bond market disappeared when there were <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 5 billion </NUMEX>of orders for <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 550 million </NUMEX>of junk bonds sold <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">last week </TIMEX>by <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Turner </ENAMEX>, ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Raymond Minella </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">co - head </ENAMEX>of merchant banking at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Merrill Lynch &amp; Co .  
5913 ` When the rally comes , insurance <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>will be leading it because they have <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">billions </NUMEX>to invest and invest they will . 
6034 There is plenty of money available from <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>who want to buy well - structured deals ; it ' s the stuff that ' s financed on a shoestring that <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>are wary of . ' 
6195 But such highly leveraged transactions seemed to have multiplied <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>, casting a pall over much of the junk market . 
6316 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Michael McNamara </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">director </ENAMEX>of fixed - income research at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Kemper Financial Services </ENAMEX>, says the quality of junk issues has been getting poorer , contributing to the slide in prices . 
6494 ` <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Last year </TIMEX>we probably bought <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>out of every <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">three </NUMEX>new deals , ' he says . 
6568 ` This <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year </TIMEX>, at best , it ' s in <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>in every <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">five </NUMEX>or <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">six </NUMEX>. 
6623 And our credit standards have n't changed <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>iota . ' 
6675 However , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">McNamara </ENAMEX>said the slide in junk is creating ` one hell of a buying opportunity ' for selective <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">buyers </ENAMEX>. 
6791 For the moment , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>seem more preoccupied with the ` bad ' junk than the ` good ' junk . 
6881 ` The market has been weak since ' the announcement of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Campeau </ENAMEX>cash squeeze and the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s subsequent bailout by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Olympia &amp; York </ENAMEX>, says Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Minella </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Merrill Lynch </ENAMEX>. 
7050 ` That really affected the market in that <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>started to ask ` What else is in trouble ? ' ' 
7144 Well before <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Campeau </ENAMEX>, though , there were signs that the junk market was stumbling through one of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its worst years </TIMEX>ever . 
7262 Despite the relatively strong economy , junk bond prices did nothing except go down , hammered by a seemingly endless trail of bad news : 
7399 - - In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">June </TIMEX>, <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">two months </TIMEX>before it would default on interest payments covering some of its <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 2 billion </NUMEX>of speculative debt securities , <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>- based <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Integrated Resources Inc . </ENAMEX>said it ran out of borrowed money . 
7611 - - In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">July </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Southmark Corp . </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Dallas </ENAMEX>- based real estate and financial services <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>with <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 1 . 3 billion </NUMEX>of junk bonds , voluntarily filed for protection under <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX>bankruptcy law . 
7799 - - By <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the end of July </TIMEX>, the difference in yield between an index of junk bonds and <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">seven - year </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>notes widened to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">more than 5 . 5 </NUMEX>percentage points . 
7953 - - In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">August </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Resorts International Inc . </ENAMEX>, which sold <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">more than $ 500 million </NUMEX>of junk bonds , suspended interest payments . 
8075 - - In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>, just as the cash squeeze hit <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Campeau </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Lomas Financial Corp . </ENAMEX>defaulted on <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 145 million </NUMEX>of notes and appeared unlikely to pay interest on a total of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 2 billion </NUMEX>of debt securities . 
8274 Meantime , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">regulators </ENAMEX>are becoming increasingly worried as the rush to leverage shows no signs of abating . 
8380 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Moody ' s </ENAMEX>says the frequency of corporate credit downgrades is the highest <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1982 </TIMEX>. 
8475 In addition , there are <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">six </NUMEX>times as many troubled <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">banks </ENAMEX>as there were in the recession of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1981 </TIMEX>, according to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Federal Deposit Insurance Corp .  
8622 ` The era of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1980s </TIMEX>is about compound interest and the reaching for it , ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">James Grant </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">editor </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Grant ' s Interest Rate Observer </ENAMEX>, an early <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">critic </ENAMEX>of the junk bond market . 
8798 ` What we ' ve begun to see is the damage to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">businesses </ENAMEX>of paying exorbitant compound interest . 
8891 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Businesses </ENAMEX>were borrowing at interest rates higher than their own earnings . 
8967 What we ' re seeing now is the wrenching readjustment of asset values to a future when speculative - grade debt will be hard to obtain rather than easy . ' 
9119 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Friday </TIMEX>' s Market Activity 
9146 Prices of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>bonds surged in the biggest rally of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the year </TIMEX>as <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">investors </ENAMEX>fled a plummeting stock market . 
9258 The benchmark <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">30 - year </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>bond was quoted <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">6 p . m . EDT </TIMEX>at <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">103 12 \/ 32 </NUMEX>, compared with <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">100 27 \/ 32 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Thursday </TIMEX>, up <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">2 1 \/ 2 </NUMEX>points . 
9381 The yield on the benchmark fell to <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">7 . 82 % </NUMEX>, the lowest since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">March 31 , 1987 </TIMEX>, according to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Technical Data Global Markets Group </ENAMEX>. 
9508 The ` flight to quality ' began late in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the day </TIMEX>and followed a precipitous fall in the stock market . 
9607 Treasurys opened lower , reacting negatively to news that the producer price index - - a measure of inflation on the wholesale level - - accelerated in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">September </TIMEX>. 
9767 Bond prices barely budged until <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">midday </TIMEX>. 
9809 Many bond market <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">participants </ENAMEX>will be closely eying the action of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Reserve </ENAMEX>, which might repeat its <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">October 1987 </TIMEX>injection of huge amounts of liquidity to buoy the financial markets and keep the economy from slowing into a recession . 
10055 Prices of municipals , investment - grade corporates and mortgage - backed bonds also rose , but lagged behind their <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Treasury </ENAMEX>counterparts .

9 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Second U . S . Circuit Court of Appeals </ENAMEX>opinion in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Arcadian Phosphate </ENAMEX>case did not repudiate the position <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Pennzoil Co . </ENAMEX>took in its dispute with <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Texaco </ENAMEX>, contrary to your <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Sept . 8 </TIMEX>article ` <ENAMEX TYPE="WORK_OF_ART:OTHER">Court Backs Texaco ' s View in Pennzoil Case - - Too Late </ENAMEX>. ' 
259 The fundamental rule of contract law applied to both cases was that <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">courts </ENAMEX>will not enforce agreements to which the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">parties </ENAMEX>did not intend to be bound . 
411 In the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Pennzoil </ENAMEX>\/ <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Texaco </ENAMEX>litigation , the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">courts </ENAMEX>found <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Pennzoil </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Getty Oil </ENAMEX>intended to be bound ; in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Arcadian Phosphates </ENAMEX>they found there was no intention to be bound . 
580 Admittedly , the principle in the cases is the same . 
632 But the outcome of a legal dispute almost always turns on the facts . 
701 And the facts , as found by the various <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">courts </ENAMEX>in these <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">two </NUMEX>lawsuits , were different . 
788 When you suggest otherwise , you leave the realm of reporting and enter the orbit of speculation . 
887 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Charles F . Vihon

9 Newspaper <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">publishers </ENAMEX>are reporting mixed <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">third - quarter </TIMEX>results , aided by favorable newsprint prices and hampered by flat or declining advertising linage , especially in the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Northeast </ENAMEX>. 
194 Adding to unsteadiness in the industry , seasonal retail ad spending patterns in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">newspapers </ENAMEX>have been upset by shifts in ownership and general hardships within the retail industry . 
374 In <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Bonwit Teller </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">B . Altman &amp; Co . </ENAMEX>department <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">stores </ENAMEX>have filed for protection from <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">creditors </ENAMEX>under <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Chapter 11 </ENAMEX>of the federal <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Bankruptcy Code </ENAMEX>, while the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">R . H . Macy &amp; Co . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Bloomingdale </ENAMEX>' s and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Saks Fifth Avenue </ENAMEX>department - store <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">chains </ENAMEX>are for sale . 
637 Many <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">papers </ENAMEX>throughout the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">country </ENAMEX>are also faced with a slowdown in classified - ad spending , a booming category for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">newspapers </ENAMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">recent years </TIMEX>. 
783 Until recently , industry <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>believed decreases in retail ad spending had bottomed out and would in fact increase in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year ' s third and fourth quarters </TIMEX>. 
944 All bets are off , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>say , because of the shifting ownership of the retail <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">chains </ENAMEX>. 
1034 ` Improved paper prices will help offset weakness in linage , but the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">retailers </ENAMEX>' problems have affected the amount of ad linage they usually run , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Edward J . Atorino </ENAMEX>, industry <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analyst </ENAMEX>for <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Salomon Brothers Inc .  
1246 ` <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Retailers </ENAMEX>are just in disarray . ' 
1282 For instance , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Gannett Co . </ENAMEX>posted <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">an 11 % </NUMEX>gain in net income , as total ad pages dropped at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">USA Today </ENAMEX>, but advertising revenue rose because of a higher circulation rate base and increased rates . 
1474 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Gannett </ENAMEX>' s <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">83 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">daily </TIMEX>and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">35 </NUMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">non - daily </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">newspapers </ENAMEX>reported a <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">3 % </NUMEX>increase in advertising and circulation revenue . 
1584 Total advertising linage was ` modestly ' lower as classified - ad volume increased , while there was ` softer demand ' for retail and national ad linage , said <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">John Curley </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Gannett </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chief executive officer </ENAMEX>.

3223 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Third - quarter </TIMEX>profit estimates for several <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>are being strongly affected by the price of newsprint , which in the last <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">two years </TIMEX>has had several price increases . 
3392 After a supply crunch caused prices to rise <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">14 % </NUMEX>since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1986 </TIMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 650 </NUMEX>a metric ton , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">analysts </ENAMEX>are encouraged , because they do n't expect a price increase for the rest of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. 
3570 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">Companies </ENAMEX>with <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">daily </TIMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">newspapers </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Northeast </ENAMEX>will need the stable newsprint prices to ease damage from weak ad linage .

9 Population Drain Ends For Midwestern <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">States  
57 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">IOWA </ENAMEX>IS MAKING a comeback . 
84 So are <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Indiana </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Ohio </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Michigan </ENAMEX>. 
119 The <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">population </ENAMEX>of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">all four </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>is on the upswing , according to new <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Census Bureau </ENAMEX>estimates , following declines throughout <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the early 1980s </TIMEX>. 
263 The gains , to be sure , are rather small . 
304 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Iowa </ENAMEX>, for instance , saw its <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">population </ENAMEX>grow by <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">11 , 000 </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>, or <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">0 . 4 % </NUMEX>, <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">between 1987 and 1988 </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Census Bureau </ENAMEX>says . 
422 Still , even that modest increase is good news for a <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">state </ENAMEX>that had n't grown at all since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1981 </TIMEX>. 
519 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Between 1987 and 1988 </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">North Dakota </ENAMEX>was the only <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">state </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Midwest </ENAMEX>to lose <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">population </ENAMEX>, a loss of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">4 , 000 </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>. 
633 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">Six </NUMEX>of the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">12 </NUMEX>midwestern <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>have been growing steadily since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1980 </TIMEX>- - <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Illinois </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Kansas </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Minnesota </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Missouri </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">South Dakota </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Wisconsin </ENAMEX>. 
775 The <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Northeast </ENAMEX>has been holding its own in the population race . 
838 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">Seven </NUMEX>of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">nine </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>have grown <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">each year </TIMEX>since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1980 </TIMEX>, including <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>, which lost <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">4 % </NUMEX>of its <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">population </ENAMEX>during <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the 1970s </TIMEX>. 
962 And although <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Pennsylvania </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Massachusetts </ENAMEX>suffered slight declines earlier in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the decade </TIMEX>, they are growing again . 
1080 At the same time , several <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>in the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">South </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">West </ENAMEX>have had their own population turnaround .

1328 Overall , though , the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">South </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">West </ENAMEX>still outpace the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Northeast </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Midwest </ENAMEX>, and fast - growing <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:STATE_PROVINCE">states </ENAMEX>like <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Florida </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">California </ENAMEX>ensure that the pattern will continue . 
1496 But the growth gap between the <ENAMEX TYPE="LOCATION:REGION">Sun Belt </ENAMEX>and other regions has clearly started narrowing . 
1587 More <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Elderly </ENAMEX>Maintain Their Independence 
1632 THANKS TO modern medicine , more <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">couples </ENAMEX>are growing old together . 
1698 And even after losing a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spouse </ENAMEX>, more of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">elderly </ENAMEX>are staying independent . 
1775 A new <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Census Bureau </ENAMEX>study of the noninstitutionalized <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">population </ENAMEX>shows that <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">64 % </NUMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">aged 65 to 74 </TIMEX>were living with a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spouse </ENAMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>, up from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">59 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1970 </TIMEX>. 
1937 This does n't mean they ' re less likely to live alone , however . 
1999 That share has remained at <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">about 24 % </NUMEX>since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1970 </TIMEX>. 
2048 What has changed is that more of the young <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">elderly </ENAMEX>are living with <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spouses </ENAMEX>rather than with other <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">relatives </ENAMEX>, such as <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">children </ENAMEX>. 
2175 In <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>, <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">10 % </NUMEX>of those <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">aged 65 to 74 lived </TIMEX>with <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">relatives </ENAMEX>other than <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spouses </ENAMEX>, down from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">15 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1970 </TIMEX>. 
2277 As <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>get even older , many become widowed . 
2324 But even among those <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">aged 75 and older </TIMEX>, the share living with a <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spouse </ENAMEX>rose slightly , to <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">40 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">38 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1970 </TIMEX>. 
2445 Like their younger <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">counterparts </ENAMEX>, the older <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">elderly </ENAMEX>are less likely to live with other <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">relatives </ENAMEX>. 
2542 <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">Only 17 % </NUMEX>of those <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">aged 75 and older </TIMEX>lived with <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">relatives </ENAMEX>other than <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">spouses </ENAMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>, down from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">26 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1970 </TIMEX>. 
2652 The likelihood of living alone beyond <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:AGE">the age of 75 </TIMEX>has increased to <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">40 % </NUMEX>from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">32 % </NUMEX>. 
2735 More <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>are remaining independent longer presumably because they are better off physically and financially . 
2849 Careers Count Most For the Well - to - Do 
2891 MANY AFFLUENT <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>place personal success and money above <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">family </ENAMEX>. 
2961 At least that ' s what a survey by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Ernst &amp; Young </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Yankelovich , Clancy , Shulman </ENAMEX>indicates . 
3052 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">Two - thirds </NUMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">respondents </ENAMEX>said they strongly felt the need to be successful in their jobs , while <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">fewer than half </NUMEX>said they strongly felt the need to spend more time with their <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">families </ENAMEX>. 
3238 Being successful in careers and spending the money they make are top priorities for this <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">group </ENAMEX>. 
3336 Unlike most studies of the affluent market , this survey excluded the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">super - rich </ENAMEX>. 
3417 Average household income for the sample was <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 194 , 000 </NUMEX>, and average net assets were reported as <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 775 , 000 </NUMEX>. 
3523 The goal was to learn about <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>of <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">today </TIMEX>' s fastest - growing income <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">groups </ENAMEX>, the upper - middle <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">class </ENAMEX>. 
3621 Although they represent <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">only 2 % </NUMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">population </ENAMEX>, they control <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">nearly one - third </NUMEX>of discretionary income . 
3729 Across the board , these <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">consumers </ENAMEX>value quality , buy what they like rather than just what they need , and appreciate products that are distinctive . 
3878 Despite their considerable incomes and assets , <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">40 % </NUMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">respondents </ENAMEX>in the study do n't feel financially secure , and <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one - fourth </NUMEX>do n't feel that they have made it . 
4042 <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">Twenty percent </NUMEX>do n't even feel they are financially well off . 
4106 Many of the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">affluent </ENAMEX>are n't comfortable with themselves , either . 
4171 <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">About 40 % </NUMEX>do n't feel they ' re more able than others . 
4223 While <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">twothirds </NUMEX>feel some guilt about being affluent , <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">only 25 % </NUMEX>give <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 2 , 500 </NUMEX>or more to charity <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">each year </TIMEX>. 
4330 <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">Thirty - five percent </NUMEX>attend religious services regularly ; at the same time , <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">60 % </NUMEX>feel that in life one sometimes has to compromise one ' s principles . 
4479 Odds and Ends

4755 The share of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">minorities </ENAMEX>in those positions has risen to <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">16 % </NUMEX>from <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">12 % </NUMEX>. . . .

4954 The amount of income divvied up for each <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">man </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">woman </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">child </ENAMEX>was <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 16 , 489 </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>, up <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">6 . 6 % </NUMEX>from <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 15 , 472 </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1987 </TIMEX>.

9 The real estate slump that ' s pushing down the price of <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>office space and housing is also affecting the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:CITY">city </ENAMEX>' s retail real estate market . 
156 In <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Manhattan </ENAMEX>, once - desirable store sites sit vacant and newly constructed space has been slow to fill . 
259 Retail real estate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">brokers </ENAMEX>say <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">tenants </ENAMEX>are reluctant to sign leases because of uncertainty about the local economy , turmoil in their own industries and a belief that rents have not yet hit bottom . 
458 ` There is an unbelievable amount of space available , ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Faith Consolo </ENAMEX>, senior <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">vice president </ENAMEX>at <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Garrick - Aug Associates Store Leasing Inc .  
599 There are <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">about 2 , 000 </NUMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">stores </ENAMEX>for rent , up from a more typical range of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">1 , 200 </NUMEX>to <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">1 , 500 </NUMEX>. 
686 ` This further confuses <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">retailers </ENAMEX>, ' she says . 
731 ` They wonder should they sign a lease if prices are still coming down ? 
802 Is this the wrong time to open a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">store </ENAMEX>? 
842 Who is going to be in the space next door ? ' 
888 In addition , Ms . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Consolo </ENAMEX>says , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">tenants </ENAMEX>usually can negotiate to pay rents that are <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">about one - quarter </NUMEX>lower than <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">landlords </ENAMEX>' initial asking price . 
1035 A handful of hot retail locations , such as the <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:HIGHWAY_STREET">57th Street </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:HIGHWAY_STREET">Madison </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:HIGHWAY_STREET">Fifth Avenue </ENAMEX>areas , have been able to sustain what many see as astronomical rents . 
1193 And , in some neighborhoods , rents have merely hit a plateau . 
1254 But on average , <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Manhattan </ENAMEX>retail rents have dropped <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">10 % to 15 % </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the past six months </TIMEX>alone , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">experts </ENAMEX>say . 
1360 That follows a more subtle decline in the prior <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">six months </TIMEX>, after <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Manhattan </ENAMEX>rents had run up rapidly since <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1986 </TIMEX>. 
1475 The same factors limiting demand for office space have affected retailing . 
1550 ` As <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:OTHER">businesses </ENAMEX>contract or depart , the number of <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">employees </ENAMEX>who might use retail services shrinks , ' says <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Edward A . Friedman </ENAMEX>, senior <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">vice president </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Helmsley Spear Inc .  
1721 He says financial problems plaguing electronics , fur and furniture <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>- - key categories in the local retail economy - - have further deflated the market . 
1881 Hardest hit are what he calls ` secondary ' sites that primarily serve neighborhood <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">residents </ENAMEX>. 
1974 In these locations , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Friedman </ENAMEX>says , ` Retailers are increasingly cautious about expanding and rents have remained steady or in some cases have declined . ' 
2130 Weakness in the restaurant industry , which is leaving retail space vacant , exacerbates the problem for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">landlords </ENAMEX>. 
2246 It is also no comfort to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">landlords </ENAMEX>and small <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">retailers </ENAMEX>when the future of larger department <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">stores </ENAMEX>, which anchor retail neighborhoods , are in doubt . 
2404 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Hooker Corp . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">parent </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Bonwit Teller </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">B . Altman ' s </ENAMEX>, is mired in bankruptcy proceedings and <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Bloomingdale ' s </ENAMEX>is for sale by its <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">owner </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Campeau Corp .  
2555 The trend toward lower rents may seem surprising given that some <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">communities </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>are bemoaning the loss of favorite local <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">businesses </ENAMEX>to high rents . 
2711 But , despite the recent softening , for many of these <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">retailers </ENAMEX>there ' s still been too big a jump from the rental rates of the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">late 1970s </TIMEX>, when their leases were signed . 
2882 Certainly , the recent drop in prices does n't mean <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Manhattan </ENAMEX>comes cheap . 
2955 <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>retail rents still run well above the going rate in other <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">U . S . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:CITY">cities </ENAMEX>. 
3035 <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:HIGHWAY_STREET">Madison </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:HIGHWAY_STREET">Fifth Avenues </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:HIGHWAY_STREET">East 57th Street </ENAMEX>can command rents of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">up to $ 500 </NUMEX>a square foot , and <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 250 </NUMEX>is not uncommon .

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel Inc . </ENAMEX>expects <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">fiscal second - quarter </TIMEX>earnings to trail <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">1988 </TIMEX>results , but anticipates that several new products will lead to a ` much stronger ' performance in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">its second half </TIMEX>. 
191 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>, a telecommunications <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>, had net income of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 272 , 000 </NUMEX>, or <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">five cents </NUMEX>a share , in its <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">year - earlier second quarter , ended Sept . 30 </TIMEX>.

361 <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">George Pierce </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chairman </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">chief executive officer </ENAMEX>, said in an interview that earnings in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the most recent quarter </TIMEX>will be <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about two cents </NUMEX>a share on revenue of just under <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 4 million </NUMEX>. 
547 The lower results , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>said , reflect a <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">12 - month </TIMEX>decline in industry sales of privately owned pay telephones , <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>' s primary business . 
691 Although Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>expects that line of business to strengthen in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the next year </TIMEX>, he said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>will also benefit from moving into other areas . 
839 Foremost among those is the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s entrance into the public facsimile business , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>said . 
939 Within <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">the next year </TIMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>expects to place <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">10 , 000 </NUMEX>fax machines , made by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Minolta </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:COUNTRY">Japan </ENAMEX>, in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:HOTEL">hotels </ENAMEX>, municipal <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">buildings </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">drugstores </ENAMEX>and other public settings around the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE_DESC:COUNTRY">country </ENAMEX>. 
1122 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>will provide a credit - card reader for the machines to collect , store and forward billing data . 
1227 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>should realize a minimum of <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 10 </NUMEX>of recurring net earnings for each machine each month . 
1340 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>has also developed an automatic call processor that will make further use of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>' s system for automating and handling credit - card calls and collect calls . 
1511 Automatic call processors will provide that system for virtually any telephone , Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>said , not just phones produced by <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Elcotel </ENAMEX>. 
1647 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>will also be producing a new line of convenience telephones , which do n't accept coins , for use in hotel <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">lobbies </ENAMEX>, office <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">lobbies </ENAMEX>, hospitality <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:BUILDING">lounges </ENAMEX>and similar settings . 
1832 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pierce </ENAMEX>estimated that the processors and convenience phones would produce <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">about $ 5 </NUMEX>of recurring net earnings for each machine each month .  

9 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:CORPORATION">Information International Inc . </ENAMEX>said it was sued by a <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">buyer </ENAMEX>of its computerized newspaper - publishing system , alleging that the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">company </ENAMEX>failed to correct deficiencies in the system .

9 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>' s decision to approve a bare - bones deficit - reduction bill without a capital - gains tax cut still leaves open the possibility of enacting a gains tax reduction <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. 
191 <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Late Friday </TIMEX><TIMEX TYPE="TIME">night </TIMEX>, the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>voted <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">87 - 7 </NUMEX>to approve <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">an estimated $ 13 . 5 billion </NUMEX>measure that had been stripped of <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">hundreds </NUMEX>of provisions that would have widened , rather than narrowed , the federal budget deficit . 
402 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Lawmakers </ENAMEX>drastically streamlined the bill to blunt criticism that it was bloated with special - interest tax breaks and spending increases . 
543 ` We ' re putting a deficit - reduction bill back in the category of being a deficit - reduction bill , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate Budget Committee </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Chairman </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">James Sasser </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Tenn . </ENAMEX>-RRB- . 
706 But <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">supporters </ENAMEX>of the trimmer legislation said that other bills would soon be moving through <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX>that could carry some of the measures that had been cast aside , including a capital - gains tax cut . 
914 In addition , the companion deficit - reduction bill already passed by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>includes a capital - gains provision . 
1028 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>- <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>negotiations are likely to begin at <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">midweek </TIMEX>and last for a while . 
1109 ` No one can predict exactly what will happen on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>side , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>Minority <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Leader </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Robert Dole </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">R . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Kan . </ENAMEX>-RRB- .

1339 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">White House </ENAMEX>Budget <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Director </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Richard Darman </ENAMEX>told <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">reporters </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">yesterday </TIMEX>that the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:GOVERNMENT">administration </ENAMEX>would n't push to keep the capital - gains cut in the final version of the bill . 
1509 ` We do n't need this as a way to get capital gains , ' he said . 
1572 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House Budget Committee </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Chairman </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Leon Panetta </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Calif . </ENAMEX>-RRB- said in an interview , ` If that ' s the signal that comes from the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">White House </ENAMEX>, that will help a great deal . ' 
1739 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>' s decision was a setback for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">President </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX>and will make approval of a capital - gains tax cut less certain <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. 
1868 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Opponents </ENAMEX>of the cut are playing hardball . 
1911 <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>Majority <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Leader </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">George Mitchell </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Maine </ENAMEX>-RRB- said he was ` confident ' that any <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>- <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>agreement on the deficit - reduction legislation would n't include a capital - gains tax cut . 
2097 And a senior <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">aide </ENAMEX>to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House Ways and Means Committee </ENAMEX>, where tax legislation originates , said there are n't any ` plans to produce another tax bill that could carry a gains tax cut <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">this year </TIMEX>. ' 
2292 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX>obvious place to attach a capital - gains tax cut , and perhaps other popular items stripped from the deficit - reduction bill , is the legislation to raise the federal borrowing limit . 
2476 Such legislation must be enacted by <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the end of the month </TIMEX>. 
2536 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>bill was pared back in an attempt to speed deficit - reduction through <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Congress </ENAMEX>. 
2626 Because the legislation has n't been completed , <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">President </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX>has until <TIMEX TYPE="TIME">midnight tonight </TIMEX>to enact across - the - board spending cuts mandated by the <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Gramm - Rudman </ENAMEX>deficit - reduction law . 
2809 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Senators </ENAMEX>hope that the need to avoid those cuts will pressure the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>to agree to the streamlined bill . 
2915 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>appears reluctant to join the <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">senators </ENAMEX>. 
2965 A key is whether <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Republicans </ENAMEX>are willing to acquiesce to their <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">colleagues </ENAMEX>' decision to drop many pet provisions . 
3093 ` Although I am encouraged by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>action , ' said <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Chairman </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Dan Rostenkowski </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Ill . </ENAMEX>-RRB- of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House Ways and Means Committee </ENAMEX>, ` it is uncertain whether a clean bill can be achieved in the upcoming conference with the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>. ' 
3324 Another big question hovering over the debate is what <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">President </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bush </ENAMEX>thinks . 
3401 He has been resisting a stripped - down bill without a guaranteed vote on his capital - gains tax cut . 
3500 But <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Republican </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">senators </ENAMEX>saw no way to overcome a procedural hurdle and garner the <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">60 </NUMEX>votes needed to win the capital - gains issue on the floor , so they went ahead with the streamlined bill . 
3691 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>bill was stripped of many popular , though revenue - losing , provisions , a number of which are included in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>- passed bill . 
3829 These include a child - care initiative and extensions of soon - to - expire tax breaks for low - income housing and research - and - development expenditures . 
3977 Also missing from the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>bill is the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>' s repeal of a law , called <ENAMEX TYPE="LAW">Section 89 </ENAMEX>, that compels <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>to give rank - and - file <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">workers </ENAMEX>comparable health benefits to top paid <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">executives </ENAMEX>. 
4168 <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">One </NUMEX>high - profile provision that was originally in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>bill but was cut out because it lost money was the proposal by <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Chairman </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Lloyd Bentsen </ENAMEX>-LRB- <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">D . </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Texas </ENAMEX>-RRB- of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate Finance Committee </ENAMEX>to expand the deduction for individual retirement accounts . 
4419 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Bentsen </ENAMEX>said he hopes the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>will consider that measure soon . 
4491 To the delight of some <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">doctors </ENAMEX>, the bill dropped a plan passed by the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Finance Committee </ENAMEX>that would have overhauled the entire physician - reimbursement system under <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Medicare </ENAMEX>. 
4664 To the detriment of many low - income <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">people </ENAMEX>, efforts to boost <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Medicaid </ENAMEX>funding , especially in rural areas , also were stricken . 
4792 Asked why <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">senators </ENAMEX>were giving up so much , <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">New Mexico </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Pete Domenici </ENAMEX>, the ranking <ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Republican </ENAMEX>on the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate Budget Committee </ENAMEX>, said , ` We ' re looking like <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">idiots </ENAMEX>. 
4955 Things had just gone too far . ' 
4988 <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Dole </ENAMEX>said that the move required sacrifice by every <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">senator </ENAMEX>. 
5054 It worked , others said , because there were no exceptions : all revenue - losing provisions were stricken . 
5159 The <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>also dropped a plan by its <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Finance Committee </ENAMEX>that would have increased the income threshold beyond which senior <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">citizens </ENAMEX>have their <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Social Security </ENAMEX>benefits reduced . 
5336 In addition , the bill dropped a plan to make permanent a <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">3 % </NUMEX>excise tax on long - distance telephone calls . 
5441 It no longer includes a plan that would have repealed what remains of the completed - contract method of accounting , which is used by military <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">contractors </ENAMEX>to reduce their tax burden . 
5622 It also drops a provision that would have permitted <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">corporations </ENAMEX>to use excess pension funds to pay health benefits for current <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">retirees </ENAMEX>. 
5762 Also stricken was a fivefold increase in the maximum <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Occupational Safety and Health Administration </ENAMEX>penalties , which would have raised <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 65 million </NUMEX>in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">fiscal 1990 </TIMEX>. 
5924 A provision that would have made the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Social Security Administration </ENAMEX>an independent <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">agency </ENAMEX>was excised . 
6029 The approval of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Senate </ENAMEX>bill was especially sweet for <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Sen . </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Mitchell </ENAMEX>, who had proposed the streamlining . 
6136 Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Mitchell </ENAMEX>' s relations with Budget <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">Director </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Darman </ENAMEX>, who pushed for a capital - gains cut to be added to the measure , have been strained since Mr . <ENAMEX TYPE="PERSON">Darman </ENAMEX>chose to bypass the <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:STATE_PROVINCE">Maine </ENAMEX><ENAMEX TYPE="NORP:POLITICAL">Democrat </ENAMEX>and deal with other <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">lawmakers </ENAMEX><TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">earlier this year </TIMEX>during a dispute over drug funding in the <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">fiscal 1989 </TIMEX>supplemental spending bill . 
6456 The deficit reduction bill contains <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 5 . 3 billion </NUMEX>in tax increases in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">fiscal 1990 </TIMEX>, and <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 26 billion </NUMEX>over <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">five years </TIMEX>. 
6571 The revenue - raising provisions , which affect mostly <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">corporations </ENAMEX>, would : 
6646 - - Prevent <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>that have made leveraged buy - outs from getting federal tax refunds resulting from losses caused by interest payments on debt issued to finance the buy - outs , effective <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">Aug . 2 , 1989 </TIMEX>. 
6850 - - Require mutual funds to include in their taxable income dividends paid to them on <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the date </TIMEX>that the dividends are declared rather than received , effective <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">the day </TIMEX>after the tax bill is enacted . 
7049 - - Close a loophole regarding employee stock ownership plans , effective <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">June 6 , 1989 </TIMEX>, that has been exploited by investment <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">bankers </ENAMEX>in corporate takeovers . 
7205 The measure repeals a <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">50 % </NUMEX>exclusion given to <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">banks </ENAMEX>on the interest from loans used to acquire securities for an ESOP , if the ESOP owns <NUMEX TYPE="PERCENT">less than 30 % </NUMEX>of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">employer </ENAMEX>' s stock . 
7381 - - Curb junk bonds by ending tax benefits for certain securities , such as <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">zero </NUMEX>- coupon bonds , that postpone cash interest payments . 
7514 - - Raise <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 851 million </NUMEX>by suspending for <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DURATION">one year </TIMEX>an automatic reduction in airport and airway taxes . 
7617 - - Speed up the collection of the payroll tax from large <ENAMEX TYPE="ORG_DESC:CORPORATION">companies </ENAMEX>, effective <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">August 1990 </TIMEX>. 
7710 - - Impose a tax on ozone - depleting <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:CHEMICAL">chemicals </ENAMEX>, such as those used in air conditioners and in <ENAMEX TYPE="SUBSTANCE:OTHER">Styrofoam </ENAMEX>, beginning at <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 10 </NUMEX>a pound starting <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next year </TIMEX>. 
7862 - - Withhold income taxes from the paychecks of certain farm <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">workers </ENAMEX>currently exempt from withholding . 
7967 - - Change the collection of gasoline excise taxes to <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">weekly </TIMEX>from <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:OTHER">semimonthly </TIMEX>, effective <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next year </TIMEX>. 
8068 - - Restrict the ability of real estate <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">owners </ENAMEX>to escape taxes by swapping <NUMEX TYPE="CARDINAL">one </NUMEX>piece of property for another instead of selling it for cash . 
8210 - - Increase to <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 6 </NUMEX>a person from <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 3 </NUMEX>the international air - passenger departure tax , and impose a <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 3 </NUMEX>- a - person tax on international departures by commercial <ENAMEX TYPE="PRODUCT_DESC:VEHICLE">ships </ENAMEX>. 
8372 The measure also includes spending cuts and increases in federal fees . 
8443 Among its provisions : 
8467 - - Reduction of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Medicare </ENAMEX>spending in <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">fiscal 1990 </TIMEX>by some <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 2 . 8 billion </NUMEX>, in part by curbing increases in reimbursements to <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">physicians </ENAMEX>. 
8600 The plan would impose a brief freeze on physician fees <TIMEX TYPE="DATE:DATE">next year </TIMEX>. 
8668 - - Removal of the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">U . S . Postal Service </ENAMEX>' s operating budget from the federal budget , reducing the deficit by <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 1 . 77 billion </NUMEX>. 
8789 A similar provision is in the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">House </ENAMEX>version . 
8836 - - Authority for the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Aviation Administration </ENAMEX>to raise <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 239 million </NUMEX>by charging fees for commercial airline - landing rights at <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">New York </ENAMEX>' s <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:AIRPORT">LaGuardia </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:AIRPORT">John F . Kennedy International Airports </ENAMEX>, <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:AIRPORT">O ' Hare International Airport </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Chicago </ENAMEX>and <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC:AIRPORT">National Airport </ENAMEX>in <ENAMEX TYPE="GPE:CITY">Washington </ENAMEX>. 
9112 - - Increases in <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Nuclear Regulatory Commission </ENAMEX>fees totaling <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 54 million </NUMEX>. 
9187 - - Direction to the <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">U . S . Coast Guard </ENAMEX>to collect <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">$ 50 million </NUMEX>from <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">users </ENAMEX>of <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Coast Guard </ENAMEX>services . 
9285 - - Raising <NUMEX TYPE="MONEY">an additional $ 43 million </NUMEX>by increasing existing <ENAMEX TYPE="ORGANIZATION:GOVERNMENT">Federal Communications Commission </ENAMEX>fees and penalties and establishing new fees for amateur radio <ENAMEX TYPE="PER_DESC">operators </ENAMEX>, ship <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:OTHER">stations </ENAMEX>and mobile radio <ENAMEX TYPE="FAC_DESC:OTHER">facilities </ENAMEX>.
